events.title: Huck's Introduction and Reference to 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer'
detailed_summary: Huck Finn introduces himself, referencing a previous book, 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer' by Mr. Mark Twain.
He asserts that while the book is largely truthful, it does contain some exaggerations or 'stretchers'.
Huck opines that lying is a common human trait, with possible exceptions like Aunt Polly, the widow, or Mary.
He confirms that these characters are featured in the aforementioned book, which he deems mostly accurate despite its embellished parts.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: You don’t know about me without you have read a book by the name of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer; but that ain’t no matter.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Aunt Polly—Tom’s Aunt Polly, she is—and Mary, and the Widow Douglas is all told about in that book, which is mostly a true book, with some stretchers, as I said before.

events.text_segment: You don’t know about me without you have read a book by the name of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer; but that ain’t no matter. That book was made by Mr. Mark Twain, and he told the truth, mainly. There was things which he stretched, but mainly he told the truth. That is nothing. I never seen anybody but lied one time or another, without it was Aunt Polly, or the widow, or maybe Mary. Aunt Polly—Tom’s Aunt Polly, she is—and Mary, and the Widow Douglas is all told about in that book, which is mostly a true book, with some stretchers, as I said before.

events.title: Acquiring Wealth and the Widow Douglas's Attempt to 'Sivilize' Huck
detailed_summary: Huck explains that the previous book concluded with him and Tom Sawyer discovering a substantial sum of money hidden by robbers, making them wealthy.
They each received six thousand dollars in gold, which Judge Thatcher invested for them, generating a dollar a day in interest for each.
The Widow Douglas adopted Huck, intending to 'sivilize' him.
Huck found the structured and 'decent' lifestyle at the Widow's house to be unbearable and eventually ran away, reverting to his old, comfortable ways.
Tom Sawyer located Huck and convinced him to return to the Widow Douglas's care by promising him membership in a new band of robbers, provided Huck maintained a respectable demeanor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now the way that the book winds up is this: Tom and me found the money that the robbers hid in the cave, and it made us rich.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I went back.

events.text_segment: Now the way that the book winds up is this: Tom and me found the money that the robbers hid in the cave, and it made us rich. We got six thousand dollars apiece—all gold. It was an awful sight of money when it was piled up. Well, Judge Thatcher he took it and put it out at interest, and it fetched us a dollar a day apiece all the year round—more than a body could tell what to do with. The Widow Douglas she took me for her son, and allowed she would sivilize me; but it was rough living in the house all the time, considering how dismal regular and decent the widow was in all her ways; and so when I couldn’t stand it no longer I lit out. I got into my old rags and my sugar-hogshead again, and was free and satisfied. But Tom Sawyer he hunted me up and said he was going to start a band of robbers, and I might join if I would go back to the widow and be respectable. So I went back.

events.title: Huck's Discomfort with 'Sivilized' Life at the Widow's
detailed_summary: Upon Huck's return, the Widow Douglas expressed her emotions openly, calling him a 'poor lost lamb' and other affectionate, though perhaps critical, names, without any harmful intent.
She compelled him to wear new clothes again, causing Huck to feel uncomfortably hot, sweaty, and restricted.
Huck describes the reinstatement of the strict household routines, beginning with the punctual supper bell.
He recounts the pre-meal ritual requiring everyone to wait while the Widow offered a somewhat discontented prayer over the food.
Huck contrasts the unappetizing nature of food items cooked separately with the superior flavor of food mixed together, as in a 'barrel of odds and ends'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she called me a lot of other names, too, but she never meant no harm by it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In a barrel of odds and ends it is different; things get mixed up, and the juice kind of swaps around, and the things go better.

events.text_segment: The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she called me a lot of other names, too, but she never meant no harm by it. She put me in them new clothes again, and I couldn’t do nothing but sweat and sweat, and feel all cramped up. Well, then, the old thing commenced again. The widow rung a bell for supper, and you had to come to time. When you got to the table you couldn’t go right to eating, but you had to wait for the widow to tuck down her head and grumble a little over the victuals, though there warn’t really anything the matter with them,—that is, nothing only everything was cooked by itself. In a barrel of odds and ends it is different; things get mixed up, and the juice kind of swaps around, and the things go better.

events.title: Huck's Fleeting Interest in Moses
detailed_summary: Following supper, the Widow Douglas attempted to instruct Huck about Moses and the Bulrushers using a book.
Initially, Huck was very keen to learn everything about Moses.
His enthusiasm quickly waned when the Widow informed him that Moses had died a long time ago.
Huck explains his disinterest by stating his general indifference towards deceased individuals.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After supper she got out her book and learned me about Moses and the Bulrushers, and I was in a sweat to find out all about him; but by-and-by she let it out that Moses had been dead a considerable long time; so then I didn’t care no more about him, because I don’t take no stock in dead people.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: so then I didn’t care no more about him, because I don’t take no stock in dead people.

events.text_segment: After supper she got out her book and learned me about Moses and the Bulrushers, and I was in a sweat to find out all about him; but by-and-by she let it out that Moses had been dead a considerable long time; so then I didn’t care no more about him, because I don’t take no stock in dead people.

**text_segment**: After supper she got out her book and learned me about Moses and the Bulrushers, and I was in a sweat to find out all about him; but by-and-by she let it out that Moses had been dead a considerable long time; so then I didn't care no more about him, because I don't take no stock in dead people.

Pretty soon I wanted to smoke, and asked the widow to let me. But she wouldn't. She said it was a mean practice and wasn't clean, and I must try to not do it any more. That is just the way with some people. They get down on a thing when they don't know nothing about it. Here she was a-bothering about Moses, which was no kin to her, and no use to anybody, being gone, you see, yet finding a power of fault with me for doing a thing that had some good in it. And she took snuff, too; of course that was all right, because she done it herself.

events.title: Conflict Over Smoking and Perceived Hypocrisy
detailed_summary: Huck felt the urge to smoke and requested permission from the Widow Douglas.
She denied his request, labeling smoking as a 'mean practice' and unclean, and advised him to abandon the habit.
Huck reflects on the tendency of some people to criticize things they know little about.
He found it ironic that the Widow concerned herself with Moses, a long-dead figure irrelevant to her, yet found fault with his smoking, a habit he believed had some merit.
Huck also observes the Widow's own use of snuff, implying a double standard since she considered her habit acceptable.

events.title: Miss Watson's Efforts to Educate and Reform Huck
detailed_summary: Miss Watson, the Widow Douglas's sister, who had recently come to live with them, began trying to educate Huck with a spelling-book.
She subjected Huck to about an hour of rigorous instruction before the Widow intervened to give him a respite.
Huck found the subsequent hour intensely boring as Miss Watson incessantly corrected his posture and manners, with admonitions like 'Don’t put your feet up there' and 'set up straight'.
When Miss Watson described 'the bad place' (hell), Huck, yearning for any form of change or excitement, impulsively declared he wished he were there, which angered her.
She then depicted 'the good place' (heaven) as an eternity of playing harps and singing, a prospect Huck found unappealing.
He privately resolved not to pursue her vision of heaven but refrained from saying so to avoid conflict.
Huck was pleased to hear Miss Watson assert that Tom Sawyer was unlikely to reach 'the good place,' as he desired to remain with his friend.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Her sister, Miss Watson, a tolerable slim old maid, with goggles on, had just come to live with her, and took a set at me now with a spelling-book.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I was glad about that, because I wanted him and me to be together.

events.text_segment:
Her sister, Miss Watson, a tolerable slim old maid, with goggles on, had just come to live with her, and took a set at me now with a spelling-book. She worked me middling hard for about an hour, and then the widow made her ease up. I couldn’t stood it much longer. Then for an hour it was deadly dull, and I was fidgety. Miss Watson would say, “Don’t put your feet up there, Huckleberry;” and “Don’t scrunch up like that, Huckleberry—set up straight;” and pretty soon she would say, “Don’t gap and stretch like that, Huckleberry—why don’t you try to behave?” Then she told me all about the bad place, and I said I wished I was there. She got mad then, but I didn’t mean no harm. All I wanted was to go somewheres; all I wanted was a change, I warn’t particular. She said it was wicked to say what I said; said she wouldn’t say it for the whole world; she was going to live so as to go to the good place. Well, I couldn’t see no advantage in going where she was going, so I made up my mind I wouldn’t try for it. But I never said so, because it would only make trouble, and wouldn’t do no good.
Now she had got a start, and she went on and told me all about the good place. She said all a body would have to do there was to go around all day long with a harp and sing, forever and ever. So I didn’t think much of it. But I never said so. I asked her if she reckoned Tom Sawyer would go there, and she said not by a considerable sight. I was glad about that, because I wanted him and me to be together.

events.title: Evening Loneliness, Superstitions, and a Bad Omen
detailed_summary: Miss Watson's persistent nagging left Huck feeling weary and isolated.
The household's enslaved individuals ('niggers') were brought in for evening prayers before everyone retired for the night.
Alone in his room with a candle, Huck attempted to find cheerful thoughts but failed, overwhelmed by a profound loneliness that made him almost wish for death.

He grew frightened by various natural sounds from the woods—rustling leaves, an owl's hoot (interpreted as a death omen), a whippoorwill and dog's cries (signifying an impending death), and an unintelligible whispering wind that sent shivers down his spine.
He also heard a sound he believed was made by a restless ghost unable to communicate its troubles.
Feeling dejected and terrified, Huck longed for companionship.
A spider crawled onto his shoulder; he instinctively flicked it off, and it landed in the candle flame, shriveling up instantly.
Huck immediately perceived this as a dire omen of bad luck, intensifying his fear.

He performed superstitious rituals—turning in his tracks three times, crossing his breast, and tying a lock of his hair with thread—to ward off witches, but he doubted their effectiveness against the misfortune of killing a spider, unlike remedies for losing a found horseshoe.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But I hadn’t no confidence. You do that when you’ve lost a horseshoe that you’ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn’t ever heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you’d killed a spider.

events.text_segment: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome. By-and-by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then everybody was off to bed. I went up to my room with a piece of candle, and put it on the table. Then I set down in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it warn’t no use. I felt so lonesome I most wished I was dead. The stars were shining, and the leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippowill and a dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was trying to whisper something to me, and I couldn’t make out what it was, and so it made the cold shivers run over me. Then away out in the woods I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell about something that’s on its mind and can’t make itself understood, and so can’t rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every night grieving. I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some company. Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it was all shriveled up. I didn’t need anybody to tell me that that was an awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and most shook the clothes off of me. I got up and turned around in my tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away. But I hadn’t no confidence. You do that when you’ve lost a horseshoe that you’ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn’t ever heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you’d killed a spider.

Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome. By and by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then everybody was off to bed. I went up to my room with a piece of candle, and put it on the table. Then I set down in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it warn't no use. I felt so lonesome I most wished I was dead. The stars were shining, and the leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippoorwill and a dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was trying to whisper something to me, and I couldn't make out what it was, and so it made the cold shivers run over me. Then away out in the woods I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell about something that's on its mind and can't make itself understood, and so can't rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every night grieving. I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some company. Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it was all shriveled up. I didn't need anybody to tell me that that was an awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and most shook the clothes off of me. I got up and turned around in my tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away. But I hadn't no confidence. You do that when you've lost a horseshoe that you've found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn't ever heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you'd killed a spider.
```

events.title: The Midnight Signal and Escape to Meet Tom Sawyer
detailed_summary: Still trembling from the spider incident, Huck sat down and decided to smoke his pipe, believing the house was sufficiently quiet for the Widow not to discover him.
After a considerable wait, he heard the distant town clock strike twelve.
An even deeper silence enveloped the surroundings.
Shortly thereafter, a twig snapped in the darkness among the trees, signaling that someone was nearby.
Huck listened intently and soon faintly discerned Tom Sawyer's signature cat-call signal, 'me-yow! me-yow!'.
Overjoyed, Huck softly mimicked the call, extinguished his candle, and stealthily climbed out of his window onto the shed roof.
He then descended to the ground, crept into the trees, and, as expected, found Tom Sawyer waiting for him.

Well, after a long time I heard the clock away off in the town go boom—boom—boom—twelve licks; and all still again—stiller than ever. Pretty soon I heard a twig snap down in the dark amongst the trees—something was a stirring. I set still and listened. Directly I could just barely hear a “me-yow! me-yow!” down there. That was good! Says I, “me-yow! me-yow!” as soft as I could, and then I put out the light and scrambled out of the window on to the shed. Then I slipped down to the ground and crawled in among the trees, and, sure enough, there was Tom Sawyer waiting for me.

I set down again, a-shaking all over, and got out my pipe for a smoke; for the house was all as still as death now, and so the widow wouldn't know. I waited what seemed a mighty long spell, just listening to the quiet that filled up the house. Then I heard the clock way off in town strike twelve. Everything got even more quiet after that, if such a thing was possible.

I was just starting to feel easy when there came a snap of a twig from out in the dark, under the trees. I froze and listened hard. Then I heard it - faint-like but clear enough - "Me-yow! Me-yow!" ```

events.title: The Close Call in the Garden
detailed_summary: Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer cautiously navigate the widow's garden path, trying to remain undetected.
Huck inadvertently makes a noise by tripping over a root, attracting the attention of Miss Watson's slave, Jim, who is near the kitchen.
Jim gets up to investigate the sound, coming very close to where Huck and Tom are concealed.
While hiding, Huck is tormented by severe itching on his ankle, ear, and back, finding it almost unbearable to stay still.
This period of tense stillness and discomfort stretches on for what feels like an eternity to Huck, though it is only several minutes.
Eventually, Jim gives up his watch, sits down on the ground between Huck and Tom, leans against a tree, and soon begins to snore, allowing Huck to feel at ease again.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We went tiptoeing along a path amongst the trees back towards the end of the widow’s garden, stooping down so as the branches wouldn’t scrape our heads.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just then Jim begun to breathe heavy; next he begun to snore—and then I was pretty soon comfortable again.

events.text_segment:
We went tiptoeing along a path amongst the trees back towards the end of the widow’s garden, stooping down so as the branches wouldn’t scrape our heads. When we was passing by the kitchen I fell over a root and made a noise. We scrouched down and laid still. Miss Watson’s big nigger, named Jim, was setting in the kitchen door; we could see him pretty clear, because there was a light behind him. He got up and stretched his neck out about a minute, listening. Then he says:
“Who dah?”
He listened some more; then he come tiptoeing down and stood right between us; we could a touched him, nearly. Well, likely it was minutes and minutes that there warn’t a sound, and we all there so close together. There was a place on my ankle that got to itching, but I dasn’t scratch it; and then my ear begun to itch; and next my back, right between my shoulders. Seemed like I’d die if I couldn’t scratch. Well, I’ve noticed that thing plenty times since. If you are with the quality, or at a funeral, or trying to go to sleep when you ain’t sleepy—if you are anywheres where it won’t do for you to scratch, why you will itch all over in upwards of a thousand places. Pretty soon Jim says:
“Say, who is you? Whar is you? Dog my cats ef I didn’ hear sumf’n. Well, I know what I’s gwyne to do: I’s gwyne to set down here and listen tell I hears it agin.”
So he set down on the ground betwixt me and Tom. He leaned his back up against a tree, and stretched his legs out till one of them most touched one of mine. My nose begun to itch. It itched till the tears come into my eyes. But I dasn’t scratch. Then it begun to itch on the inside. Next I got to itching underneath. I didn’t know how I was going to set still. This miserableness went on as much as six or seven minutes; but it seemed a sight longer than that. I was itching in eleven different places now. I reckoned I couldn’t stand it more’n a minute longer, but I set my teeth hard and got ready to try. Just then Jim begun to breathe heavy; next he begun to snore—and then I was pretty soon comfortable again.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak:

```
We went tiptoeing along a path amongst the trees back towards the end of the widow's garden, stooping down so as the branches wouldn't scrape our heads. There was the soft glow of moonlight filtering through the leaves above us. Tom was in the lead, and I was right behind him, both of us careful not to make a sound.

All of a sudden, my foot caught on an old tree root that stuck up out of the ground, and I nearly fell flat on my face. I made a bit of a scuffling noise trying to catch myself, and we froze right where we stood.

"What's that?" came Jim's voice from over by the kitchen door. He was Miss Watson's big slave, and we could see him sitting there in the moonlight. He got up from where he was sitting and stretched himself, listening.

"Who dah?" he called out, peering into the darkness where we were.

Tom and me, we didn't dare breathe. Jim came tiptoeing down the path, so close I could've reached out and touched him if I'd wanted to get caught. He stopped almost right between us and stood there, listening.

Then the worst thing happened. My ankle started to itch something terrible. And then my ear. And then my back, right in the middle where I couldn't reach it. Seemed like the more I couldn't scratch, the worse it got. I thought I'd die if I couldn't scratch. This kept up for what seemed like forever - I reckon it was only a few minutes, but it felt like hours. I was about ready to cry, it was so bad.

Finally, Jim said, "Well, I knows I heard somethin', but I reckon it ain't nothin' but one of dem cats." He sat down on the ground not five feet from where I was hiding, leaned his back against a tree, and before long he was snoring away.

I felt myself relax then, and the itching seemed to go away all at once, now that I could scratch if I wanted to.
```

events.title: Tom's Prank and the Birth of Jim's Witch Story
detailed_summary: Once Jim is asleep, Tom signals Huck, and they stealthily move away.
Tom proposes tying Jim to the tree for amusement, but Huck advises against it, worried Jim might wake up and cause a disturbance, revealing Huck's absence from his room.
Tom then decides he needs more candles and plans to sneak into the kitchen to get them, despite Huck's apprehension.
They enter the kitchen, procure three candles, and Tom conscientiously leaves five cents on the table as payment.
Huck is anxious to depart, but Tom is determined to play a prank on the sleeping Jim.
Tom carefully crawls to Jim, takes his hat, and hangs it on a tree limb directly above Jim's head. Jim stirs but doesn't awaken.
Later, Jim recounts a fantastical tale of being bewitched by witches, claiming they put him in a trance, rode him all over the State, and then placed his hat on the limb as evidence.
With each retelling, Jim's story becomes more extravagant, eventually including journeys to New Orleans and then worldwide, resulting in extreme exhaustion and saddle-boils.
This narrative brings Jim considerable renown and respect among other slaves, who would travel from miles around to hear his account.
Jim treasures the five-cent piece, wearing it as a charm supposedly given by the devil, which he believes grants him supernatural abilities like curing people and summoning witches.
His preoccupation with his supernatural experiences and newfound status significantly diminishes his effectiveness as a servant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom he made a sign to me—kind of a little noise with his mouth—and we went creeping away on our hands and knees.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Jim was most ruined for a servant, because he got stuck up on account of having seen the devil and been rode by witches.

events.text_segment:
Tom he made a sign to me—kind of a little noise with his mouth—and we went creeping away on our hands and knees. When we was ten foot off Tom whispered to me, and wanted to tie Jim to the tree for fun. But I said no; he might wake and make a disturbance, and then they’d find out I warn’t in. Then Tom said he hadn’t got candles enough, and he would slip in the kitchen and get some more. I didn’t want him to try. I said Jim might wake up and come. But Tom wanted to resk it; so we slid in there and got three candles, and Tom laid five cents on the table for pay. Then we got out, and I was in a sweat to get away; but nothing would do Tom but he must crawl to where Jim was, on his hands and knees, and play something on him. I waited, and it seemed a good while, everything was so still and lonesome.
As soon as Tom was back we cut along the path, around the garden fence, and by-and-by fetched up on the steep top of the hill the other side of the house. Tom said he slipped Jim’s hat off of his head and hung it on a limb right over him, and Jim stirred a little, but he didn’t wake. Afterwards Jim said the witches bewitched him and put him in a trance, and rode him all over the State, and then set him under the trees again, and hung his hat on a limb to show who done it. And next time Jim told it he said they rode him down to New Orleans; and, after that, every time he told it he spread it more and more, till by-and-by he said they rode him all over the world, and tired him most to death, and his back was all over saddle-boils. Jim was monstrous proud about it, and he got so he wouldn’t hardly notice the other niggers. Niggers would come miles to hear Jim tell about it, and he was more looked up to than any nigger in that country. Strange niggers would stand with their mouths open and look him all over, same as if he was a wonder. Niggers is always talking about witches in the dark by the kitchen fire; but whenever one was talking and letting on to know all about such things, Jim would happen in and say, “Hm! What you know ’bout witches?” and that nigger was corked up and had to take a back seat. Jim always kept that five-center piece round his neck with a string, and said it was a charm the devil give to him with his own hands, and told him he could cure anybody with it and fetch witches whenever he wanted to just by saying something to it; but he never told what it was he said to it. Niggers would come from all around there and give Jim anything they had, just for a sight of that five-center piece; but they wouldn’t touch it, because the devil had had his hands on it. Jim was most ruined for a servant, because he got stuck up on account of having seen the devil and been rode by witches.

events.title: Forming Tom Sawyer's Gang and the Blood Oath
detailed_summary: From a hilltop, Tom and Huck observe the quiet village, the grand river, and the starlit sky.
They descend and rendezvous with Jo Harper, Ben Rogers, and several other boys at an old tanyard.
The assembled group commandeers a skiff and rows approximately two and a half miles downriver to a distinctive scar on the hillside, where they disembark.
Tom guides them to a cleverly concealed opening in a thicket of bushes, revealing the entrance to a cave.
After everyone solemnly swears to maintain secrecy, they illuminate candles and crawl into the cave.
They proceed about two hundred yards through the cave's passages until it widens, then Tom leads them through another hidden opening into a secluded, damp, and cold chamber.
In this chamber, Tom formally announces the establishment of a band of robbers to be named 'Tom Sawyer's Gang'.
He declares that membership requires taking a sacred oath and signing one's name in blood.
All the boys present express their eagerness to join.
Tom then reads aloud an elaborate oath he has prepared, which binds every boy to the gang and its secrets.

The oath includes severe penalties: any boy ordered to kill a person (and their family) who wronged a gang member must do so without delay; this act was to be marked by hacking a cross into the victim's breast.

The oath further stipulates that non-members using the gang's mark face lawsuits or death, while any gang member betraying secrets will have his throat cut, his body burned, his ashes scattered, his name erased from the list with blood, and a curse placed upon his memory.
The boys are deeply impressed by the oath, deeming it 'real beautiful,' and inquire if Tom devised it entirely himself.

events.text_segment:
Well, when Tom and me got to the edge of the hilltop we looked away down into the village and could see three or four lights twinkling, where there was sick folks, maybe; and the stars over us was sparkling ever so fine; and down by the village was the river, a whole mile broad, and awful still and grand. We went down the hill and found Jo Harper and Ben Rogers, and two or three more of the boys, hid in the old tanyard. So we unhitched a skiff and pulled down the river two mile and a half, to the big scar on the hillside, and went ashore.
We went to a clump of bushes, and Tom made everybody swear to keep the secret, and then showed them a hole in the hill, right in the thickest part of the bushes. Then we lit the candles, and crawled in on our hands and knees. We went about two hundred yards, and then the cave opened up. Tom poked about amongst the passages, and pretty soon ducked under a wall where you wouldn’t a noticed that there was a hole. We went along a narrow place and got into a kind of room, all damp and sweaty and cold, and there we stopped. Tom says:
“Now, we’ll start this band of robbers and call it Tom Sawyer’s Gang. Everybody that wants to join has got to take an oath, and write his name in blood.”
Everybody was willing. So Tom got out a sheet of paper that he had wrote the oath on, and read it. It swore every boy to stick to the band, and never tell any of the secrets; and if anybody done anything to any boy in the band, whichever boy was ordered to kill that person and his family must do it, and he mustn’t eat and he mustn’t sleep till he had killed them and hacked a cross in their breasts, which was the sign of the band. And nobody that didn’t belong to the band could use that mark, and if he did he must be sued; and if he done it again he must be killed. And if anybody that belonged to the band told the secrets, he must have his throat cut, and then have his carcass burnt up and the ashes scattered all around, and his name blotted off of the list with blood and never mentioned again by the gang, but have a curse put on it and be forgot forever.
Everybody said it was a real beautiful oath, and asked Tom if he got it out of his own head.

events.title: Oath Amendments and Huck's Peculiar Pledge
detailed_summary: Tom acknowledges that while some parts of the oath were his own invention, the remainder was drawn from pirate and robber storybooks, asserting that all respectable gangs had similar codes.
A suggestion arises to add a clause about killing the families of any boy who reveals gang secrets, an idea Tom readily incorporates into the oath with a pencil.
Ben Rogers then raises a practical issue: Huck Finn lacks a family, which conflicts with the new rule about killing family members of traitors.
Tom initially inquires about Huck's father, but it's established that he is a long-absent drunkard.
The boys deliberate and lean towards excluding Huck, reasoning that the 'family-to-kill' requirement must apply to everyone for fairness.
Feeling distressed and on the verge of tears, Huck suddenly proposes Miss Watson, his guardian, as the 'family' member the gang could kill if he were to betray them.
This unconventional offer is accepted by all the boys, clearing the way for Huck's inclusion in the gang.
Following this, each boy pricks his finger to provide blood for signing the oath, and Huck makes his mark on the document.

He said, some of it, but the rest was out of pirate-books and robber-books, and every gang that was high-toned had it.
Some thought it would be good to kill the families of boys that told the secrets. Tom said it was a good idea, so he took a pencil and wrote it in. Then Ben Rogers says:
“Here’s Huck Finn, he hain’t got no family; what you going to do ’bout him?”
“Well, hain’t he got a father?” says Tom Sawyer.
“Yes, he’s got a father, but you can’t never find him these days. He used to lay drunk with the hogs in the tanyard, but he hain’t been seen in these parts for a year or more.”
They talked it over, and they was going to rule me out, because they said every boy must have a family or somebody to kill, or else it wouldn’t be fair and square for the others. Well, nobody could think of anything to do—everybody was stumped, and set still. I was most ready to cry; but all at once I thought of a way, and so I offered them Miss Watson—they could kill her. Everybody said:
“Oh, she’ll do. That’s all right. Huck can come in.”
Then they all stuck a pin in their fingers to get blood to sign with, and I made my mark on the paper.

He said, some of it, but the rest was out of pirate-books and robber-books, and every gang that was high-toned had it.

"But robbers always have it," said Tom, with the confidence of one who knows his subject thoroughly.

"Don't all honest gangs have to swear an oath?" asked one of the boys.

"Of course they do," Tom replied. "How else would you keep secrets? And we ought to have a rule that if anybody tells the secrets, we must kill them and all their family," he added, his eyes gleaming with the dramatic possibility.

"Yes—yes!" they all agreed.

Tom took out his pencil and scrawled the new rule on the paper with evident satisfaction.

Ben Rogers spoke up suddenly. "But Huck ain't got no family."

"Well, he's got a father, ain't he?" said Tom.

"Yes, but you can't never find him these days. He's drunk most of the time, and hain't been seen in these parts for more than a year."

The boys fell silent, considering this problem. It seemed unfair that some members would risk their families while Huck risked nothing.

"I reckon we can't let him join," one of the boys said reluctantly.

Huck's face fell, and his eyes grew moist. He had been so excited about belonging to the gang, and now it was slipping away.

"I'll tell you what," he said suddenly, his voice quavering a little. "Miss Watson—she's good enough to kill. She takes care of me now. You can kill her."

The boys looked at each other, impressed by this sacrifice. It was a generous offer, and it solved their problem neatly.

"That'll do," said Tom gravely. "That's fair. Now everybody got to stab their fingers a little to sign with blood."

Tom produced a pin, and each boy pricked his finger in turn, squeezing out drops of blood to make his mark on the paper. When it came Huck's turn, he made his mark with the same solemn pride as the others, now a full member of Tom Sawyer's gang.
```

events.title: Defining the Gang's Criminal Enterprise
detailed_summary: Ben Rogers seeks clarification on the gang's primary activities.
Tom Sawyer authoritatively states their business will consist solely of 'robbery and murder'.

He distinguishes their intended operations from mere 'burglary' like stealing cattle, proclaiming they will be 'highwaymen,' stopping stagecoaches, killing occupants, and seizing their money and watches.

When asked if killing is always necessary, Tom affirms it is generally the best approach, according to authorities (from his books), although some captives might be brought to the cave and held for 'ransom'.
Ben Rogers questions the meaning of 'ransom,' a term Tom admits he doesn't fully understand but insists upon because it is featured in his books.
Tom consistently uses book precedents as the ultimate justification for the gang's rules and intended actions.
Pressed further about ransoming, Tom speculates it might mean keeping prisoners until they die, an interpretation Ben Rogers finds more comprehensible.
Ben Rogers then raises concerns about the impracticality of guarding prisoners, but Tom dismisses this, citing book protocols for guards.
The discussion shifts to the treatment of female victims, with Ben Rogers asking if women will also be killed.

Tom, again referencing his readings, explains that women are not to be killed; instead, they are to be brought to the cave, treated with utmost politeness, and will inevitably fall in love with their captors and choose to stay.
Ben Rogers expresses skepticism about this romantic outcome but acquiesces, albeit with a prediction that the cave will soon become overcrowded with women and unransomed men.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now,” says Ben Rogers, “what’s the line of business of this Gang?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But go ahead, I ain’t got nothing to say.”

events.text_segment:
“Now,” says Ben Rogers, “what’s the line of business of this Gang?”
“Nothing only robbery and murder,” Tom said.
“But who are we going to rob?—houses, or cattle, or—”
“Stuff! stealing cattle and such things ain’t robbery; it’s burglary,” says Tom Sawyer. “We ain’t burglars. That ain’t no sort of style. We are highwaymen. We stop stages and carriages on the road, with masks on, and kill the people and take their watches and money.”
“Must we always kill the people?”
“Oh, certainly. It’s best. Some authorities think different, but mostly it’s considered best to kill them—except some that you bring to the cave here, and keep them till they’re ransomed.”
“Ransomed? What’s that?”
“I don’t know. But that’s what they do. I’ve seen it in books; and so of course that’s what we’ve got to do.”
“But how can we do it if we don’t know what it is?”
“Why, blame it all, we’ve got to do it. Don’t I tell you it’s in the books? Do you want to go to doing different from what’s in the books, and get things all muddled up?”
“Oh, that’s all very fine to say, Tom Sawyer, but how in the nation are these fellows going to be ransomed if we don’t know how to do it to them?—that’s the thing I want to get at. Now, what do you reckon it is?”
“Well, I don’t know. But per’aps if we keep them till they’re ransomed, it means that we keep them till they’re dead.”
“Now, that’s something like. That’ll answer. Why couldn’t you said that before? We’ll keep them till they’re ransomed to death; and a bothersome lot they’ll be, too—eating up everything, and always trying to get loose.”
“How you talk, Ben Rogers. How can they get loose when there’s a guard over them, ready to shoot them down if they move a peg?”
“A guard! Well, that is good. So somebody’s got to set up all night and never get any sleep, just so as to watch them. I think that’s foolishness. Why can’t a body take a club and ransom them as soon as they get here?”
“Because it ain’t in the books so—that’s why. Now, Ben Rogers, do you want to do things regular, or don’t you?—that’s the idea. Don’t you reckon that the people that made the books knows what’s the correct thing to do? Do you reckon you can learn ’em anything? Not by a good deal. No, sir, we’ll just go on and ransom them in the regular way.”
“All right. I don’t mind; but I say it’s a fool way, anyhow. Say, do we kill the women, too?”
“Well, Ben Rogers, if I was as ignorant as you I wouldn’t let on. Kill the women? No; nobody ever saw anything in the books like that. You fetch them to the cave, and you’re always as polite as pie to them; and by-and-by they fall in love with you, and never want to go home any more.”
“Well, if that’s the way I’m agreed, but I don’t take no stock in it. Mighty soon we’ll have the cave so cluttered up with women, and fellows waiting to be ransomed, that there won’t be no place for the robbers. But go ahead, I ain’t got nothing to say.”

events.title: A Frightened Robber and the Gang's Adjournment
detailed_summary: Little Tommy Barnes, who had fallen asleep, is awakened and reacts with fear and tears, expressing his desire to go home to his mother and abandon his role as a robber.
The other boys mock him, calling him a 'cry-baby,' which provokes his anger.
In retaliation, Tommy threatens to expose all the gang's secrets.
Tom Sawyer quickly defuses the situation by bribing Tommy with five cents to maintain his silence.
Tom then suggests they all return home and arrange to meet the following week to carry out their first robbery and murders.
Ben Rogers notes his availability is limited to Sundays and proposes starting then.
However, the consensus among the boys is that engaging in such activities on a Sunday would be wicked, thereby settling that specific timing issue.
They agree to convene again soon to select an appropriate day for their inaugural operation.
Before dispersing, Tom Sawyer is elected as the gang's first captain, and Jo Harper as the second captain.
The boys then depart for their homes.

Huck manages to sneak back into his room through the window just as dawn is breaking, finding his new clothes soiled with grease and clay, and feeling completely exhausted from the night's adventures.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My new clothes was all greased up and clayey, and I was dog-tired.

events.text_segment:
Little Tommy Barnes was asleep now, and when they waked him up he was scared, and cried, and said he wanted to go home to his ma, and didn’t want to be a robber any more.
So they all made fun of him, and called him cry-baby, and that made him mad, and he said he would go straight and tell all the secrets. But Tom give him five cents to keep quiet, and said we would all go home and meet next week, and rob somebody and kill some people.
Ben Rogers said he couldn’t get out much, only Sundays, and so he wanted to begin next Sunday; but all the boys said it would be wicked to do it on Sunday, and that settled the thing. They agreed to get together and fix a day as soon as they could, and then we elected Tom Sawyer first captain and Jo Harper second captain of the Gang, and so started home.
I clumb up the shed and crept into my window just before day was breaking. My new clothes was all greased up and clayey, and I was dog-tired.

The boys all hooted at him, and called him cry-baby, and that made him mad, and he said he would tell all the secrets, and then Tom gave him five cents to keep quiet, and said they would all go home and meet again next week, and rob somebody and kill some people.

Ben Rogers said he couldn't get out only Sundays, and so he wanted to begin next Sunday; but all the boys said it would be wicked to do it on Sunday, and that settled the thing. They agreed to get together and fix a day as soon as they could, and then they elected Tom Sawyer first captain and Jo Harper second captain of the Gang, and so started home.

Huck Finn climbed in by his window just at daybreak, and was dog-tired, and his new clothes were in a sad way, greased and clayey from the night's adventures.
```

events.title: Huck's Disillusionment with Prayer
detailed_summary: Huck is reprimanded by Miss Watson for his untidy clothes, but the Widow Douglas kindly cleans him, inspiring a temporary desire in Huck to behave.
Miss Watson attempts to instruct Huck in prayer, asserting that any request made through prayer would be granted.
Huck puts this to the test by praying for a fish-line and hooks, but he only receives the line, leading him to doubt the efficacy of prayer for material wants.
Despite several attempts, Huck is unable to obtain hooks through prayer.
When Huck asks Miss Watson to try praying on his behalf, she dismisses him as foolish without providing any further explanation, leaving Huck perplexed.

events.title: Huck Ponders Prayer, Spiritual Gifts, and Two Providences
detailed_summary: Huck contemplates the nature of prayer, questioning why it doesn't work for practical matters like recovering Deacon Winn's lost money or the widow's stolen snuffbox, or even for Miss Watson to become thinner.
He concludes that there is no substance to this kind of prayer.
Huck shares his skepticism with the Widow Douglas, who explains that prayer is meant for obtaining 'spiritual gifts,' which involve helping others selflessly.
Huck finds this concept unappealing, as he sees no personal advantage, particularly if it means helping Miss Watson.
He reflects on the contrasting versions of Providence presented by the Widow (appealing) and Miss Watson (harsh), identifying them as two separate entities.
Huck decides he would prefer to align with the Widow's Providence, should it accept him, despite his feelings of ignorance and unworthiness.

I went and told the widow about it, and she said the thing a body could get by praying for it was “spiritual gifts.” This was too many for me, but she told me what she meant—I must help other people, and do everything I could for other people, and look out for them all the time, and never think about myself. This was including Miss Watson, as I took it. I went out in the woods and turned it over in my mind a long time, but I couldn’t see no advantage about it—except for the other people; so at last I reckoned I wouldn’t worry about it any more, but just let it go. events.title: News of Pap's Drowning and Huck's Skepticism
detailed_summary: Huck expresses his comfort that his abusive father, Pap, has not been seen for over a year, as he wishes to avoid him.
News circulates that a drowned man, presumed to be Pap based on his size, ragged clothing, and unusually long hair, has been discovered in the river.
The man's face was too decomposed for a definitive identification.
Huck, however, recalls a crucial detail: drowned men typically float face down, whereas this body was found floating on its back.
Based on this observation, Huck deduces that the deceased was not his father but likely a woman dressed in men's clothing.
This realization brings back Huck's discomfort, as he now expects his father will eventually reappear, a prospect he dreads.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Pap he hadn’t been seen for more than a year, and that was comfortable for me; I didn’t want to see him no more.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I judged the old man would turn up again by-and-by, though I wished he wouldn’t.

events.text_segment: Pap he hadn’t been seen for more than a year, and that was comfortable for me; I didn’t want to see him no more. He used to always whale me when he was sober and could get his hands on me; though I used to take to the woods most of the time when he was around. Well, about this time he was found in the river drownded, about twelve mile above town, so people said. They judged it was him, anyway; said this drownded man was just his size, and was ragged, and had uncommon long hair, which was all like pap; but they couldn’t make nothing out of the face, because it had been in the water so long it warn’t much like a face at all. They said he was floating on his back in the water. They took him and buried him on the bank. But I warn’t comfortable long, because I happened to think of something. I knowed mighty well that a drownded man don’t float on his back, but on his face. So I knowed, then, that this warn’t pap, but a woman dressed up in a man’s clothes. So I was uncomfortable again. I judged the old man would turn up again by-and-by, though I wished he wouldn’t.

He used to always whale me when he was sober and could get his hands on me; though I used to take to the woods most of the time when he was around. Well, about this time he was found in the river drowned, about twelve mile above town, so people said. They judged it was him, anyway; said this drowned man was just his size, and was ragged, and had uncommon long hair, which was all like pap; but they couldn't make nothing out of the face, because it had been in the water so long it warn't much like a face at all. They said he was floating on his back in the water. They took him and buried him on the bank. But I warn't comfortable long, because I happened to think of something. I knowed mighty well that a drowned man don't float on his back, but on his face. So I knowed, then, that this warn't pap, but a woman dressed up in a man's clothes. So I was uncomfortable again. I judged the old man would turn up again by and by, though I wished he wouldn't.

events.title: Tom Sawyer's Gang and the Disappointing 'Ambuscade'
detailed_summary: Huck and the other boys engage in playing 'robbers' for about a month, after which Huck and eventually all the boys resign from the gang.
Their activities were purely imaginary; they never actually robbed or harmed anyone, only pretending to attack targets like hog-drivers and women with market goods.
Tom Sawyer used fanciful terms for ordinary items, calling hogs 'ingots' and vegetables 'julery,' and the gang would meet in a cave to boast about their fictional exploits.
Huck, however, could not see any real benefit or 'profit' in these games.

Tom Sawyer announces a major 'ambuscade' based on supposed intelligence that a large group of Spanish merchants and wealthy Arabs, complete with elephants, camels, and vast treasures, would be camping nearby.
Though Huck doubts their ability to overcome such a force, his curiosity about seeing camels and elephants motivates him to participate.
The grandly planned attack turns out to be on nothing more than a Sunday-school picnic, specifically a primer-class.
The gang disrupts the picnic, chasing the children and managing to secure only some doughnuts and jam, along with a few trivial items, before the teacher intervenes and forces them to flee.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We played robber now and then about a month, and then I resigned.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We busted it up, and chased the children up the hollow; but we never got anything but some doughnuts and jam, though Ben Rogers got a rag doll, and Jo Harper got a hymn-book and a tract; and then the teacher charged in, and made us drop everything and cut.

events.text_segment: We played robber now and then about a month, and then I resigned. All the boys did. We hadn’t robbed nobody, hadn’t killed any people, but only just pretended. We used to hop out of the woods and go charging down on hog-drivers and women in carts taking garden stuff to market, but we never hived any of them. Tom Sawyer called the hogs “ingots,” and he called the turnips and stuff “julery,” and we would go to the cave and powwow over what we had done, and how many people we had killed and marked. But I couldn’t see no profit in it. One time Tom sent a boy to run about town with a blazing stick, which he called a slogan (which was the sign for the Gang to get together), and then he said he had got secret news by his spies that next day a whole parcel of Spanish merchants and rich A-rabs was going to camp in Cave Hollow with two hundred elephants, and six hundred camels, and over a thousand “sumter” mules, all loaded down with di’monds, and they didn’t have only a guard of four hundred soldiers, and so we would lay in ambuscade, as he called it, and kill the lot and scoop the things. He said we must slick up our swords and guns, and get ready. He never could go after even a turnip-cart but he must have the swords and guns all scoured up for it, though they was only lath and broomsticks, and you might scour at them till you rotted, and then they warn’t worth a mouthful of ashes more than what they was before. I didn’t believe we could lick such a crowd of Spaniards and A-rabs, but I wanted to see the camels and elephants, so I was on hand next day, Saturday, in the ambuscade; and when we got the word we rushed out of the woods and down the hill. But there warn’t no Spaniards and A-rabs, and there warn’t no camels nor no elephants. It warn’t anything but a Sunday-school picnic, and only a primer-class at that. We busted it up, and chased the children up the hollow; but we never got anything but some doughnuts and jam, though Ben Rogers got a rag doll, and Jo Harper got a hymn-book and a tract; and then the teacher charged in, and made us drop everything and cut.

events.title: Tom's Imaginative Justifications for a Failed Raid
detailed_summary: Huck directly questions Tom Sawyer about the absence of the promised diamonds, A-rabs, and elephants following their failed 'ambuscade.'
Tom insists that all these elements were indeed present but were made invisible to Huck because of his ignorance and lack of familiarity with books like 'Don Quixote.'
He attributes the transformation of the wealthy caravan into a simple Sunday-school picnic to 'enchantment' carried out by hostile magicians merely to spite the gang.
When Huck logically suggests that their next course of action should be to target these magicians, Tom dismisses Huck's practical idea, calling him a 'numskull.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I didn’t see no di’monds, and I told Tom Sawyer so.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom Sawyer said I was a numskull.

events.text_segment: I didn’t see no di’monds, and I told Tom Sawyer so. He said there was loads of them there, anyway; and he said there was A-rabs there, too, and elephants and things. I said, why couldn’t we see them, then? He said if I warn’t so ignorant, but had read a book called Don Quixote, I would know without asking. He said it was all done by enchantment. He said there was hundreds of soldiers there, and elephants and treasure, and so on, but we had enemies which he called magicians; and they had turned the whole thing into an infant Sunday-school, just out of spite. I said, all right; then the thing for us to do was to go for the magicians. Tom Sawyer said I was a numskull.

events.title: Huck's Empirical Test of Genies and Dismissal of Tom's Fantasies
detailed_summary: Tom Sawyer explains that magicians can summon powerful genies, capable of immense destruction, who are as tall as trees and as large as churches.

He describes how these genies appear dramatically with thunder and lightning when an old tin lamp or iron ring is rubbed, and they are compelled to obey any command given by the one who summoned them.
Commands can range from building enormous diamond palaces filled with chewing gum to fetching an emperor's daughter for marriage, all to be completed overnight.
Huck questions the genies' sense in not keeping the treasures for themselves and states that if he were a genie, he wouldn't respond so readily to someone rubbing a lamp.
Tom reiterates that genies have no choice but to obey, regardless of their size or power, and calls Huck a 'saphead' for not understanding.
Huck contemplates Tom's claims for a few days and then decides to conduct an experiment.
He takes an old tin lamp and an iron ring into the woods and rubs them vigorously, hoping to summon genies to build a palace he could sell.
When no genies appear, Huck concludes that Tom Sawyer's tales about A-rabs, elephants, and genies are simply lies.
He surmises that Tom might believe his own fantastical stories, but Huck sees the reality of the situation: the supposed adventure bore all the hallmarks of an ordinary Sunday-school event.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Why,” said he, “a magician could call up a lot of genies, and they would hash you up like nothing before you could say Jack Robinson.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It had all the marks of a Sunday-school.

events.text_segment:
“Why,” said he, “a magician could call up a lot of genies, and they would hash you up like nothing before you could say Jack Robinson. They are as tall as a tree and as big around as a church.”
“Well,” I says, “s’pose we got some genies to help us—can’t we lick the other crowd then?”
“How you going to get them?”
“I don’t know. How do they get them?”
“Why, they rub an old tin lamp or an iron ring, and then the genies come tearing in, with the thunder and lightning a-ripping around and the smoke a-rolling, and everything they’re told to do they up and do it. They don’t think nothing of pulling a shot-tower up by the roots, and belting a Sunday-school superintendent over the head with it—or any other man.”
“Who makes them tear around so?”
“Why, whoever rubs the lamp or the ring. They belong to whoever rubs the lamp or the ring, and they’ve got to do whatever he says. If he tells them to build a palace forty miles long out of di’monds, and fill it full of chewing-gum, or whatever you want, and fetch an emperor’s daughter from China for you to marry, they’ve got to do it—and they’ve got to do it before sun-up next morning, too. And more: they’ve got to waltz that palace around over the country wherever you want it, you understand.”
“Well,” says I, “I think they are a pack of flat-heads for not keeping the palace themselves ’stead of fooling them away like that. And what’s more—if I was one of them I would see a man in Jericho before I would drop my business and come to him for the rubbing of an old tin lamp.”
“How you talk, Huck Finn. Why, you’d have to come when he rubbed it, whether you wanted to or not.”
“What! and I as high as a tree and as big as a church? All right, then; I would come; but I lay I’d make that man climb the highest tree there was in the country.”
“Shucks, it ain’t no use to talk to you, Huck Finn. You don’t seem to know anything, somehow—perfect saphead.”
I thought all this over for two or three days, and then I reckoned I would see if there was anything in it. I got an old tin lamp and an iron ring, and went out in the woods and rubbed and rubbed till I sweat like an Injun, calculating to build a palace and sell it; but it warn’t no use, none of the genies come. So then I judged that all that stuff was only just one of Tom Sawyer’s lies. I reckoned he believed in the A-rabs and the elephants, but as for me I think different. It had all the marks of a Sunday-school.

events.title: Huck's Gradual Adaptation to Civilized Life
detailed_summary: Huck notes the passage of several months into winter.
He recounts his progress in school, learning basic literacy and arithmetic up to a certain point, though he expresses a lack of interest in mathematics.
His initial dislike for school has lessened, and he finds ways to cope, such as playing hookey, which, paradoxically, makes school more tolerable due to the subsequent punishment.
He is also becoming more accustomed to the Widow Douglas's civilized routines.
Despite this adaptation, he still yearns for his old, freer lifestyle, occasionally sneaking out to sleep in the woods.
He acknowledges a growing, albeit small, appreciation for some aspects of his new life.
The Widow Douglas has observed his progress, remarking that he is improving slowly but surely and that she is no longer embarrassed by him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, three or four months run along, and it was well into the winter now.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She said she warn’t ashamed of me.

events.text_segment:
Well, three or four months run along, and it was well into the winter now. I had been to school most all the time and could spell and read and write just a little, and could say the multiplication table up to six times seven is thirty-five, and I don’t reckon I could ever get any further than that if I was to live forever. I don’t take no stock in mathematics, anyway.
At first I hated the school, but by-and-by I got so I could stand it. Whenever I got uncommon tired I played hookey, and the hiding I got next day done me good and cheered me up. So the longer I went to school the easier it got to be. I was getting sort of used to the widow’s ways, too, and they warn’t so raspy on me. Living in a house and sleeping in a bed pulled on me pretty tight mostly, but before the cold weather I used to slide out and sleep in the woods sometimes, and so that was a rest to me. I liked the old ways best, but I was getting so I liked the new ones, too, a little bit. The widow said I was coming along slow but sure, and doing very satisfactory. She said she warn’t ashamed of me.

I had been to school most all the time and could spell and read and write just a little, and could say the multiplication table up to six times seven is thirty-five, and I don't reckon I could ever get any further than that if I was to live forever. I don't take no stock in mathematics, anyway.

At first I hated the school, but by and by I got so I could stand it. Whenever I got uncommon tired I played hookey, and the hiding I got next day done me good and cheered me up. So the longer I went to school the easier it got to be. I was getting sort of used to the widow's ways, too, and they warn't so raspy on me. Living in a house and sleeping in a bed pulled on me pretty tight mostly, but before the cold weather I used to slide out and sleep in the woods sometimes, and so that was a rest to me. I liked the old ways best, but I was getting so I liked the new ones, too, a little bit. The widow said I was coming along slow but sure, and doing very satisfactory. She said she warn't ashamed of me.

events.title: Ominous Salt Spilling and Foreboding
detailed_summary: Huck accidentally knocks over the salt-cellar during breakfast, a sign he interprets as bad luck.
He quickly tries to perform a superstitious ritual by throwing salt over his left shoulder to ward off the misfortune.
Miss Watson intervenes, scolding him for making a mess and preventing him from completing his ritual.
The Widow Douglas speaks kindly on Huck's behalf, but Huck believes this won't negate the impending bad luck.
He leaves breakfast feeling anxious and apprehensive, wondering how and when the bad luck will manifest.
Huck feels powerless against this particular omen, deciding to simply remain alert and dejected.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One morning I happened to turn over the salt-cellar at breakfast.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There is ways to keep off some kinds of bad luck, but this wasn’t one of them kind; so I never tried to do anything, but just poked along low-spirited and on the watch-out.

events.text_segment: One morning I happened to turn over the salt-cellar at breakfast. I reached for some of it as quick as I could to throw over my left shoulder and keep off the bad luck, but Miss Watson was in ahead of me, and crossed me off. She says, “Take your hands away, Huckleberry; what a mess you are always making!” The widow put in a good word for me, but that warn’t going to keep off the bad luck, I knowed that well enough. I started out, after breakfast, feeling worried and shaky, and wondering where it was going to fall on me, and what it was going to be. There is ways to keep off some kinds of bad luck, but this wasn’t one of them kind; so I never tried to do anything, but just poked along low-spirited and on the watch-out.

events.title: Discovery of Pap's Tracks in the Snow
detailed_summary: Huck goes to the front garden and climbs over the stile.
He notices fresh footprints in the new snow.
The tracks indicate someone came from the quarry, lingered near the stile, and then walked around the garden fence instead of entering, which Huck finds puzzling.
Upon closer examination, he identifies a distinctive mark in the left boot-heel: a cross made with nails, a superstitious ward against the devil.
Huck instantly recognizes this as a sign of his father, Pap.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I went down to the front garden and clumb over the stile where you go through the high board fence.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a cross in the left boot-heel made with big nails, to keep off the devil.

events.text_segment: I went down to the front garden and clumb over the stile where you go through the high board fence. There was an inch of new snow on the ground, and I seen somebody’s tracks. They had come up from the quarry and stood around the stile a while, and then went on around the garden fence. It was funny they hadn’t come in, after standing around so. I couldn’t make it out. It was very curious, somehow. I was going to follow around, but I stooped down to look at the tracks first. I didn’t notice anything at first, but next I did. There was a cross in the left boot-heel made with big nails, to keep off the devil.

events.title: Huck's Desperate Attempt to Offload His Fortune
detailed_summary: Reacting immediately to the discovery of his father's tracks, Huck flees downhill, constantly checking over his shoulder.
He arrives breathless at Judge Thatcher's house.
Judge Thatcher initially assumes Huck is there for his interest money, noting a recent deposit of over one hundred and fifty dollars.
Huck urgently states he doesn't want the interest or his principal sum of six thousand dollars and insists on giving it all to the Judge.
The Judge is taken aback and confused by Huck's request.
Huck pleads with the Judge to accept the money without asking questions, explaining that this would prevent him from having to lie.
Judge Thatcher, after some thought, reinterprets Huck's offer as a sale, drafting a document stating he has "bought" the property for a consideration of one dollar.
Huck signs the paper and departs.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was up in a second and shinning down the hill.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I signed it, and left.

events.text_segment:
I was up in a second and shinning down the hill. I looked over my shoulder every now and then, but I didn’t see nobody. I was at Judge Thatcher’s as quick as I could get there. He said:
“Why, my boy, you are all out of breath. Did you come for your interest?”
“No, sir,” I says; “is there some for me?”
“Oh, yes, a half-yearly is in, last night—over a hundred and fifty dollars. Quite a fortune for you. You had better let me invest it along with your six thousand, because if you take it you’ll spend it.”
“No, sir,” I says, “I don’t want to spend it. I don’t want it at all—nor the six thousand, nuther. I want you to take it; I want to give it to you—the six thousand and all.”
He looked surprised. He couldn’t seem to make it out. He says:
“Why, what can you mean, my boy?”
I says, “Don’t you ask me no questions about it, please. You’ll take it—won’t you?”
He says:
“Well, I’m puzzled. Is something the matter?”
“Please take it,” says I, “and don’t ask me nothing—then I won’t have to tell no lies.”
He studied a while, and then he says:
“Oho-o! I think I see. You want to sell all your property to me—not give it. That’s the correct idea.”
Then he wrote something on a paper and read it over, and says:
“There; you see it says ‘for a consideration.’ That means I have bought it of you and paid you for it. Here’s a dollar for you. Now you sign it.”
So I signed it, and left.

events.title: Seeking Answers from Jim's Magical Hair-Ball
detailed_summary: Huck recalls that Jim, owned by Miss Watson, possesses a magical hair-ball taken from an ox's stomach, believed to contain an omniscient spirit.
That night, Huck visits Jim, convinced his Pap has returned due to the tracks he found.
Huck wants to know Pap's intentions: what he plans to do and whether he will stay.
Jim attempts to consult the hair-ball by speaking to it and dropping it, but it remains unresponsive.
Jim explains that the hair-ball sometimes requires payment to speak.
Huck offers an old, obviously counterfeit quarter, admitting its poor quality but hoping the hair-ball might not notice, keeping the dollar from Judge Thatcher a secret.
Jim, after inspecting the coin, devises a plan to make it appear legitimate by embedding it in a raw Irish potato overnight, a method Huck recognizes but had forgotten.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Watson’s nigger, Jim, had a hair-ball as big as your fist, which had been took out of the fourth stomach of an ox, and he used to do magic with it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Well, I knowed a potato would do that before, but I had forgot it.

events.text_segment: Miss Watson’s nigger, Jim, had a hair-ball as big as your fist, which had been took out of the fourth stomach of an ox, and he used to do magic with it. He said there was a spirit inside of it, and it knowed everything. So I went to him that night and told him pap was here again, for I found his tracks in the snow. What I wanted to know was, what he was going to do, and was he going to stay? Jim got out his hair-ball and said something over it, and then he held it up and dropped it on the floor. It fell pretty solid, and only rolled about an inch. Jim tried it again, and then another time, and it acted just the same. Jim got down on his knees, and put his ear against it and listened. But it warn’t no use; he said it wouldn’t talk. He said sometimes it wouldn’t talk without money. I told him I had an old slick counterfeit quarter that warn’t no good because the brass showed through the silver a little, and it wouldn’t pass nohow, even if the brass didn’t show, because it was so slick it felt greasy, and so that would tell on it every time. (I reckoned I wouldn’t say nothing about the dollar I got from the judge.) I said it was pretty bad money, but maybe the hair-ball would take it, because maybe it wouldn’t know the difference. Jim smelt it and bit it and rubbed it, and said he would manage so the hair-ball would think it was good. He said he would split open a raw Irish potato and stick the quarter in between and keep it there all night, and next morning you couldn’t see no brass, and it wouldn’t feel greasy no more, and so anybody in town would take it in a minute, let alone a hair-ball. Well, I knowed a potato would do that before, but I had forgot it.

events.title: The Hair-Ball's Prophecy and Pap's Ominous Return
detailed_summary: After placing the counterfeit quarter under the hair-ball, Jim listens again and reports that the hair-ball is now willing to speak.
Jim relays the hair-ball's prophecy to Huck.
Regarding Pap, the hair-ball reveals he is undecided about staying or leaving, influenced by two opposing "angels," one white and one black, making his ultimate actions unpredictable.
For Huck, the hair-ball predicts a life with considerable trouble and joy, periods of sickness and injury followed by recovery.
It also foresees two significant women in Huck's life, one light-haired and one dark-haired, one rich and one poor, with Huck marrying the poor one first and then the rich one.
Crucially, the hair-ball warns Huck to avoid water and risks, as it foresees he is destined to be hanged.
Later that night, upon entering his room, Huck finds his father, Pap, waiting for him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Jim put the quarter under the hair-ball, and got down and listened again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When I lit my candle and went up to my room that night there sat pap his own self!

events.text_segment:
Jim put the quarter under the hair-ball, and got down and listened again. This time he said the hair-ball was all right. He said it would tell my whole fortune if I wanted it to. I says, go on. So the hair-ball talked to Jim, and Jim told it to me. He says:
“Yo’ ole father doan’ know yit what he’s a-gwyne to do. Sometimes he spec he’ll go ’way, en den agin he spec he’ll stay. De bes’ way is to res’ easy en let de ole man take his own way. Dey’s two angels hoverin’ roun’ ’bout him. One uv ’em is white en shiny, en t’other one is black. De white one gits him to go right a little while, den de black one sail in en bust it all up. A body can’t tell yit which one gwyne to fetch him at de las’. But you is all right. You gwyne to have considable trouble in yo’ life, en considable joy. Sometimes you gwyne to git hurt, en sometimes you gwyne to git sick; but every time you’s gwyne to git well agin. Dey’s two gals flyin’ ’bout you in yo’ life. One uv ’em’s light en t’other one is dark. One is rich en t’other is po’. You’s gwyne to marry de po’ one fust en de rich one by en by. You wants to keep ’way fum de water as much as you kin, en don’t run no resk, ’kase it’s down in de bills dat you’s gwyne to git hung.”
When I lit my candle and went up to my room that night there sat pap his own self!

Jim put the quarter under the hair-ball, and got down and listened again. This time he said the hair-ball was all right. He said it would tell my fortune if I wanted it to. I says, yes, I wanted it to.

"Yo' ole father doan' know yit what he's a-gwyne to do. Sometimes he spec he'll go 'way, en den agin he spec he'll stay. De bes' way is to res' easy en let de ole man take his own way. Dey's two angels hoverin' roun' 'bout him. One uv 'em is white en shiny, en t'other one is black. De white one gits him to go right a little while, den de black one sail in en bust it all up. A body can't tell yit which one gwyne to fetch him at de las'. But you is all right. You gwyne to have considable trouble in yo' life, en considable joy. Sometimes you gwyne to git hurt, en sometimes you gwyne to git sick; but every time you's gwyne to git well agin. Dey's two gals flyin' 'bout you in yo' life. One uv 'em's light en t'other one is dark. One is rich en t'other is po'. You's gwyne to marry de po' one fust en de rich one by en by. You wants to keep 'way fum de water as much as you kin, en don't run no resk, 'kase it's down in de bills dat you's gwyne to git hung."

When I lit my candle and went up to my room that night there sat pap—his own self!
```

events.title: Pap's Unexpected Return and Wretched Appearance
detailed_summary: Huck encounters his father, Pap, unexpectedly in his room after closing the door.
Despite an initial jolt of surprise, Huck quickly realizes he is no longer as afraid of Pap as he once was.
Pap is depicted as around fifty years old, with long, tangled, greasy black hair that partially obscures his eyes, and equally unkempt black whiskers.
His face is described as having an unnatural, sickly white color, compared to that of a tree-toad or a fish-belly.
His attire consists merely of rags.
He is observed sitting with one ankle on the other knee, revealing a damaged boot through which two of his toes protrude, and which he occasionally moves.
His old black slouch hat, misshapen with a caved-in top, lies on the floor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had shut the door to.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His hat was laying on the floor—an old black slouch with the top caved in, like a lid.

events.text_segment:
I had shut the door to. Then I turned around and there he was. I used to be scared of him all the time, he tanned me so much. I reckoned I was scared now, too; but in a minute I see I was mistaken—that is, after the first jolt, as you may say, when my breath sort of hitched, he being so unexpected; but right away after I see I warn’t scared of him worth bothring about.
He was most fifty, and he looked it. His hair was long and tangled and greasy, and hung down, and you could see his eyes shining through like he was behind vines. It was all black, no gray; so was his long, mixed-up whiskers. There warn’t no color in his face, where his face showed; it was white; not like another man’s white, but a white to make a body sick, a white to make a body’s flesh crawl—a tree-toad white, a fish-belly white. As for his clothes—just rags, that was all. He had one ankle resting on t’other knee; the boot on that foot was busted, and two of his toes stuck through, and he worked them now and then. His hat was laying on the floor—an old black slouch with the top caved in, like a lid.
