events.title: Imminent Danger: Jim's Hideout on Jackson's Island Revealed
detailed_summary: Mrs. Loftus responds that many people still believe Jim committed the murder and expect his capture soon.
When Huck asks if they are still actively searching for Jim, Mrs. Loftus, calling Huck "innocent," points out that a $300 reward is a significant incentive.
She confides that she personally believes Jim is not far away, a sentiment she hasn't widely shared.
She recounts a recent conversation with elderly neighbors who live in a log shanty, who mentioned that Jackson's Island is rarely visited and uninhabited.
This information, coupled with her memory of seeing smoke near the head of the island a day or two earlier, led her to suspect Jim might be hiding there.
She decided the island was worth investigating.
Although she hasn't seen smoke since and speculates Jim might have departed if it was him, she informed her husband about her suspicions.
Her husband, who had been upriver, returned that day, and she told him about the smoke just two hours prior to Huck's arrival; he and another man intend to search the island.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Oh, no, not everybody. A good many thinks he done it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was gone up the river; but he got back to-day, and I told him as soon as he got here two hours ago.”

events.text_segment:
“Oh, no, not everybody. A good many thinks he done it. But they’ll get the nigger pretty soon now, and maybe they can scare it out of him.”
“Why, are they after him yet?”
“Well, you’re innocent, ain’t you! Does three hundred dollars lay around every day for people to pick up? Some folks think the nigger ain’t far from here. I’m one of them—but I hain’t talked it around. A few days ago I was talking with an old couple that lives next door in the log shanty, and they happened to say hardly anybody ever goes to that island over yonder that they call Jackson’s Island. Don’t anybody live there? says I. No, nobody, says they. I didn’t say any more, but I done some thinking. I was pretty near certain I’d seen smoke over there, about the head of the island, a day or two before that, so I says to myself, like as not that nigger’s hiding over there; anyway, says I, it’s worth the trouble to give the place a hunt. I hain’t seen any smoke sence, so I reckon maybe he’s gone, if it was him; but husband’s going over to see—him and another man. He was gone up the river; but he got back to-day, and I told him as soon as he got here two hours ago.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
"Oh, no, not everybody. A good many thinks he done it. But you needn't be afeard. They'll never find him, and they couldn't prove he done it if they did find him. The old man'll be mighty mad, for a spell, but he'll come around by-and-by."

"Why?"

"Because he said he would. He said he'd cowhide me till I was black and blue if I didn't raise some money for him. I borrowed three dollars from Judge Thatcher, and pap took it and got drunk and went a-blowing around and cussing and whooping and carrying on; and he kept it up all over town, with a tin pan, till most midnight; then they jailed him, and next day they had him before court, and jailed him again for a week. But he said he was boss of his son, and he'd make it warm for him."

"Well, he hain't come back sence, and they ain't looking for him to come. Hadn't he been drunk, he'd a never raised no ruckus. Judge Thatcher and the widow's going to try to get the court to take me away from him and let one of them be my guardian; but it's new judges and new lawyers now, and they don't know the old man; so they say they'll have to let it go, and I reckon it'll be so."

events.title: Cracks in the Disguise: Huck's Nervous Errors and Name Slip-up
detailed_summary: The news of the impending search for Jim makes Huck extremely anxious, unable to sit still.
To occupy his trembling hands, he picks up a needle and attempts to thread it, performing the task poorly.
When Mrs. Loftus pauses, Huck looks up to see her observing him with a curious smile.
He puts the needle down and, feigning interest (though genuinely concerned), asks if her husband is going to the island that night.
Mrs. Loftus confirms they will go after midnight.
Huck questions whether waiting for daylight would offer better visibility for the search.
She counters that the darkness is advantageous, as Jim would likely be asleep, making it easier for them to locate his campfire if he has one.
Huck admits he hadn't considered that possibility.
Mrs. Loftus continues to scrutinize him, making Huck increasingly uncomfortable.
She then asks him to repeat his name.
Flustered, Huck stammers, "M—Mary Williams."
It immediately strikes him that he previously stated his name was Sarah, and he feels cornered, fearing his anxiety is evident.
Mrs. Loftus points out his earlier use of the name Sarah.
Huck quickly improvises, claiming his full name is Sarah Mary Williams and that people use either Sarah or Mary.
Mrs. Loftus seemingly accepts this explanation.
Huck feels a momentary sense of relief but still wishes to be elsewhere and is unable to meet her gaze.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had got so uneasy I couldn’t set still.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I couldn’t look up yet.

events.text_segment:
I had got so uneasy I couldn’t set still. I had to do something with my hands; so I took up a needle off of the table and went to threading it. My hands shook, and I was making a bad job of it. When the woman stopped talking I looked up, and she was looking at me pretty curious and smiling a little. I put down the needle and thread, and let on to be interested—and I was, too—and says:
“Three hundred dollars is a power of money. I wish my mother could get it. Is your husband going over there to-night?”
“Oh, yes. He went up-town with the man I was telling you of, to get a boat and see if they could borrow another gun. They’ll go over after midnight.”
“Couldn’t they see better if they was to wait till daytime?”
“Yes. And couldn’t the nigger see better, too? After midnight he’ll likely be asleep, and they can slip around through the woods and hunt up his camp fire all the better for the dark, if he’s got one.”
“I didn’t think of that.”
The woman kept looking at me pretty curious, and I didn’t feel a bit comfortable. Pretty soon she says,
“What did you say your name was, honey?”
“M—Mary Williams.”
Somehow it didn’t seem to me that I said it was Mary before, so I didn’t look up—seemed to me I said it was Sarah; so I felt sort of cornered, and was afeared maybe I was looking it, too. I wished the woman would say something more; the longer she set still the uneasier I was. But now she says:
“Honey, I thought you said it was Sarah when you first come in?”
“Oh, yes’m, I did. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah’s my first name. Some calls me Sarah, some calls me Mary.”
“Oh, that’s the way of it?”
“Yes’m.”
I was feeling better then, but I wished I was out of there, anyway. I couldn’t look up yet.

I had got so uneasy I couldn't set still. So I took up a needle off of the table and went to threading it. My hands shook, and I was making a poor job of it. "Three hundred dollars is a power of money. I wish my mother could get it. Is your husband going over to the island to-night?"

"Oh, yes. He went up-town with the man I was telling you about, to get a boat and see if they could borrow another gun. They'll go over after midnight."

"Couldn't they see better if they was to wait till daytime?"

"Yes. And couldn't the nigger see better, too? After midnight he'll likely be asleep, and they can slip around through the woods and hunt up his camp fire all the better for the dark, if he's got one."

"I didn't think of that."

She kept looking at me steady, and I began to feel pretty uncomfortable. Then she says:

"What did you say your name was, honey?"

"M—Mary Williams."

Somehow it didn't seem to me that I said it was Mary before, so I didn't look up—seemed to me I said it was Sarah; so I felt sort of cornered, and was afeared maybe I was looking it, too. I wished I was out of there. I wished she would say something more; the longer she set still the uneasier I was. But now she says:

"Honey, I thought you said it was Sarah when you first come in?"

"Oh, yes'm, I did. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah's my first name. Some calls me Sarah, some calls me Mary."

"Oh, that's the way of it?"

"Yes'm."

I was feeling better then, but I wished I was out of there, anyway. I couldn't look up yet.
```

events.title: The Unmasking: Judith Loftus Exposes Huck as a Boy
characters: Huck (disguise failing, revealed as a boy)
detailed_summary: Mrs. Loftus shifts the conversation to discussing difficult economic times, their poverty, and the boldness of rats in their house, which momentarily calms Huck's nerves.
She comments on the rat problem, noting their frequent appearances.
She explains she keeps items ready to throw at them when alone, showing Huck a bar of lead twisted into a knot, claiming to be a good shot generally but currently hampered by a recently wrenched arm.
She demonstrates by throwing at a rat but misses widely, exclaiming "Ouch!" due to her arm.
She then asks Huck to try hitting the next rat.
Though anxious for her husband's return and wanting to leave, Huck complies and throws the lead, coming close to hitting a rat, which earns him praise from Mrs. Loftus.
She retrieves the lead and brings back a hank of yarn, requesting Huck to hold it for her while she talks about her and her husband's affairs.
While Huck is holding the yarn, she advises him to watch for rats and keep the lead handy in his lap.
At that moment, she drops the lead into Huck's lap; he instinctively claps his legs together to catch it.
After about a minute, she takes back the yarn, looks him directly and pleasantly in the face, and asks for his real name, suggesting it might be Bill, Tom, or Bob.
Huck is visibly shaken but attempts to maintain his charade, pleading with her not to make fun of a poor girl and offering to leave if he is in the way.
Mrs. Loftus reassures him, insisting he stay and promising not to harm or report him, stating she knows his secret: he is a runaway apprentice, and that's no serious offense.
She expresses sympathy for his presumed bad treatment and encourages him to confide in her, promising her help and that of her husband.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, the woman fell to talking about how hard times was, and how poor they had to live, and how the rats was as free as if they owned the place, and so forth and so on, and then I got easy again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tell me all about it now, that’s a good boy.”

events.text_segment:
Well, the woman fell to talking about how hard times was, and how poor they had to live, and how the rats was as free as if they owned the place, and so forth and so on, and then I got easy again. She was right about the rats. You’d see one stick his nose out of a hole in the corner every little while. She said she had to have things handy to throw at them when she was alone, or they wouldn’t give her no peace. She showed me a bar of lead twisted up into a knot, and said she was a good shot with it generly, but she’d wrenched her arm a day or two ago, and didn’t know whether she could throw true now. But she watched for a chance, and directly banged away at a rat; but she missed him wide, and said “Ouch!” it hurt her arm so. Then she told me to try for the next one. I wanted to be getting away before the old man got back, but of course I didn’t let on. I got the thing, and the first rat that showed his nose I let drive, and if he’d a stayed where he was he’d a been a tolerable sick rat. She said that was first-rate, and she reckoned I would hive the next one. She went and got the lump of lead and fetched it back, and brought along a hank of yarn which she wanted me to help her with. I held up my two hands and she put the hank over them, and went on talking about her and her husband’s matters. But she broke off to say:
“Keep your eye on the rats. You better have the lead in your lap, handy.”
So she dropped the lump into my lap just at that moment, and I clapped my legs together on it and she went on talking. But only about a minute. Then she took off the hank and looked me straight in the face, and very pleasant, and says:
“Come, now, what’s your real name?”
“Wh—what, mum?”
“What’s your real name? Is it Bill, or Tom, or Bob?—or what is it?”
I reckon I shook like a leaf, and I didn’t know hardly what to do. But I says:
“Please to don’t poke fun at a poor girl like me, mum. If I’m in the way here, I’ll—”
“No, you won’t. Set down and stay where you are. I ain’t going to hurt you, and I ain’t going to tell on you, nuther. You just tell me your secret, and trust me. I’ll keep it; and, what’s more, I’ll help you. So’ll my old man if you want him to. You see, you’re a runaway ’prentice, that’s all. It ain’t anything. There ain’t no harm in it. You’ve been treated bad, and you made up your mind to cut. Bless you, child, I wouldn’t tell on you. Tell me all about it now, that’s a good boy.”

events.title: A New Fabrication: Huck's Tale of a Runaway Apprentice and Geographical Misstep
detailed_summary: Realizing his disguise is completely compromised, Huck decides to confess, but first makes Mrs. Loftus promise not to betray him.
He then invents a new story: he claims his parents are deceased and that he was legally indentured to a harsh farmer living thirty miles from the river.
He explains that the farmer's mistreatment became unbearable, so he seized an opportunity to escape when the farmer was away for a couple of days.
According to this new tale, he stole some of the farmer's daughter's old clothes for a disguise and has spent three nights traveling the thirty miles, hiding and sleeping during the daytime.
He adds that he brought a bag of bread and meat from home, which sustained him throughout the journey.
He states his intention was to reach the town of Goshen, where he believed his uncle, Abner Moore, would provide for him.
Mrs. Loftus then informs him that he is not in Goshen, but in St. Petersburg, and Goshen is actually ten miles further up the river.
She speculates that the man who gave him directions must have been drunk, as he directed him incorrectly at a fork in the road.
Huck concedes the man did seem intoxicated but says it no longer matters and that he must press on to reach Goshen before daylight.
Mrs. Loftus detains him for a moment, offering to prepare a snack for him to take on his journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So I said it wouldn’t be no use to try to play it any longer, and I would just make a clean breast and tell her everything, but she musn’t go back on her promise.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You might want it.”

events.text_segment:
So I said it wouldn’t be no use to try to play it any longer, and I would just make a clean breast and tell her everything, but she musn’t go back on her promise. Then I told her my father and mother was dead, and the law had bound me out to a mean old farmer in the country thirty mile back from the river, and he treated me so bad I couldn’t stand it no longer; he went away to be gone a couple of days, and so I took my chance and stole some of his daughter’s old clothes and cleared out, and I had been three nights coming the thirty miles. I traveled nights, and hid daytimes and slept, and the bag of bread and meat I carried from home lasted me all the way, and I had a-plenty. I said I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me, and so that was why I struck out for this town of Goshen.
“Goshen, child? This ain’t Goshen. This is St. Petersburg. Goshen’s ten mile further up the river. Who told you this was Goshen?”
“Why, a man I met at daybreak this morning, just as I was going to turn into the woods for my regular sleep. He told me when the roads forked I must take the right hand, and five mile would fetch me to Goshen.”
“He was drunk, I reckon. He told you just exactly wrong.”
“Well, he did act like he was drunk, but it ain’t no matter now. I got to be moving along. I’ll fetch Goshen before daylight.”
“Hold on a minute. I’ll put you up a snack to eat. You might want it.”

Then I told her my father and mother was dead, and the law had bound me out to a mean old farmer in the country thirty mile back from the river, and he treated me so mean I couldn't stand it no longer; he went away to be gone a couple of days, and so I took my chance and stole some of his daughter's old clothes and cleared out, and I had been three nights coming the thirty miles. I traveled nights, and hid daytimes and slept, and the bag of bread and meat I carried from home lasted me all the way, and I had a-plenty. I said I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me, and so that was why I struck out for this town of Goshen.

"Goshen, child? This ain't Goshen. This is St. Petersburg. Goshen's ten mile further up the river. Who told you this was Goshen?"

"Why, a man I met at daybreak this morning, just as I was going to turn into the woods for my regular sleep. He told me when the roads forked I must take the right hand, and five mile would fetch me to Goshen."

"He was drunk, I reckon. He told you just exactly wrong."

"Well, he did act like he was drunk, but it ain't no matter now. I got to be moving along. I'll fetch Goshen before daylight."

"Hold on a minute. I'll put you up a snack to eat. You might want it."

events.title: Lessons in Deception: Judith Loftus's Advice and Revelations
detailed_summary: After preparing a snack for Huck, Mrs. Loftus tests his rural knowledge.

She asks him a series of questions: which end of a laying cow gets up first, then a horse, which side of a tree moss grows on, and whether fifteen browsing cows on a hillside eat with their heads pointed in the same direction.
Huck answers all correctly, prompting Mrs. Loftus to remark that he has indeed lived in the country, implying she suspected he might have been trying to deceive her again.
She then asks for his real name once more, and Huck gives "George Peters."
Mrs. Loftus advises him to remember the name George and not to forget and claim it's Elexander later, then try to combine them if caught.
She tells him not to wear old calico dresses when impersonating a girl, saying he makes a poor girl but might fool men.

She then explains the specific actions that revealed he was a boy: when threading a needle, a boy holds the thread still and brings the needle to it, while a woman does the opposite; when throwing, a boy throws stiff-armed from the shoulder, unlike a girl's awkward overhead motion; and when catching something in her lap, a girl throws her knees apart, while Huck clapped his together.
She admits she spotted him as a boy when he was threading the needle and devised the other tests just to be certain.
Introducing herself as Mrs. Judith Loftus, she playfully addresses him by a string of his aliases and offers to help if he gets into trouble.
She advises him to take the river road all the way to Goshen and to carry shoes and socks next time he tramps, warning that the river road is rocky and his feet will suffer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So she put me up a snack, and says:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The river road’s a rocky one, and your feet’ll be in a condition when you get to Goshen, I reckon.”

events.text_segment:
So she put me up a snack, and says:
“Say, when a cow’s laying down, which end of her gets up first? Answer up prompt now—don’t stop to study over it. Which end gets up first?”
“The hind end, mum.”
“Well, then, a horse?”
“The for’rard end, mum.”
“Which side of a tree does the moss grow on?”
“North side.”
“If fifteen cows is browsing on a hillside, how many of them eats with their heads pointed the same direction?”
“The whole fifteen, mum.”
“Well, I reckon you have lived in the country. I thought maybe you was trying to hocus me again. What’s your real name, now?”
“George Peters, mum.”
“Well, try to remember it, George. Don’t forget and tell me it’s Elexander before you go, and then get out by saying it’s George Elexander when I catch you. And don’t go about women in that old calico. You do a girl tolerable poor, but you might fool men, maybe. Bless you, child, when you set out to thread a needle don’t hold the thread still and fetch the needle up to it; hold the needle still and poke the thread at it; that’s the way a woman most always does, but a man always does t’other way. And when you throw at a rat or anything, hitch yourself up a tiptoe and fetch your hand up over your head as awkward as you can, and miss your rat about six or seven foot. Throw stiff-armed from the shoulder, like there was a pivot there for it to turn on, like a girl; not from the wrist and elbow, with your arm out to one side, like a boy. And, mind you, when a girl tries to catch anything in her lap she throws her knees apart; she don’t clap them together, the way you did when you catched the lump of lead. Why, I spotted you for a boy when you was threading the needle; and I contrived the other things just to make certain. Now trot along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble you send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, which is me, and I’ll do what I can to get you out of it. Keep the river road all the way, and next time you tramp take shoes and socks with you. The river road’s a rocky one, and your feet’ll be in a condition when you get to Goshen, I reckon.”

events.title: Urgent Escape: Huck Warns Jim and They Flee Jackson's Island
detailed_summary: After leaving Mrs. Loftus's house, Huck walks about fifty yards up the riverbank before stealthily retracing his steps to his hidden canoe, located some distance below the house.
He jumps into the canoe and paddles away quickly, heading upstream far enough to reach the head of Jackson's Island before starting to cross the river.
He removes his sun-bonnet, no longer needing it to obscure his vision.
While in the middle of the river, he hears a clock faintly striking eleven.
Upon reaching the head of the island, despite being winded, he doesn't rest but immediately pushes into the timber towards his old campsite.
There, on a high and dry spot, he starts a substantial fire, likely intended as a decoy.
He then jumps back into his canoe and paddles as hard as he can for a mile and a half down to their current hiding place.
He lands and makes his way through the woods and up the ridge to the cavern where Jim is sound asleep on the ground.
Huck urgently rouses Jim, telling him there isn't a moment to lose because they are being pursued.
Jim, without asking any questions or uttering a word, immediately begins to work with a fervor that demonstrates his profound fear.
Within the next half hour, they manage to load all their worldly possessions onto their raft, which is then ready to be pushed out from its concealed spot in a willow cove.
Their first act is to extinguish their campfire at the cavern, and they maintain complete darkness outside afterwards.
Huck takes the canoe a short distance from the shore to scout for any pursuing boats, but the darkness from stars and shadows makes visibility poor.
Finally, they maneuver the raft out and silently drift downstream in the shadows, passing the foot of the island without speaking a word.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I went up the bank about fifty yards, and then I doubled on my tracks and slipped back to where my canoe was, a good piece below the house.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then we got out the raft and slipped along down in the shade, past the foot of the island dead still—never saying a word.

events.text_segment:
I went up the bank about fifty yards, and then I doubled on my tracks and slipped back to where my canoe was, a good piece below the house. I jumped in, and was off in a hurry. I went up-stream far enough to make the head of the island, and then started across. I took off the sun-bonnet, for I didn’t want no blinders on then. When I was about the middle I heard the clock begin to strike, so I stops and listens; the sound come faint over the water but clear—eleven. When I struck the head of the island I never waited to blow, though I was most winded, but I shoved right into the timber where my old camp used to be, and started a good fire there on a high and dry spot.
Then I jumped in the canoe and dug out for our place, a mile and a half below, as hard as I could go. I landed, and slopped through the timber and up the ridge and into the cavern. There Jim laid, sound asleep on the ground. I roused him out and says:
“Git up and hump yourself, Jim! There ain’t a minute to lose. They’re after us!”
Jim never asked no questions, he never said a word; but the way he worked for the next half an hour showed about how he was scared. By that time everything we had in the world was on our raft, and she was ready to be shoved out from the willow cove where she was hid. We put out the camp fire at the cavern the first thing, and didn’t show a candle outside after that.
I took the canoe out from the shore a little piece, and took a look; but if there was a boat around I couldn’t see it, for stars and shadows ain’t good to see by. Then we got out the raft and slipped along down in the shade, past the foot of the island dead still—never saying a word.

events.title: Narrow Escape and Deceptive Tactics
detailed_summary: Around one in the morning, Huck and Jim finally managed to get their slow-moving raft past the island.

They had a contingency plan to use their canoe and head for the Illinois shore if a boat approached, but they realized in their haste they hadn't packed any essential supplies like a gun, fishing gear, or food into the canoe.
Huck acknowledged their poor judgment in keeping all their provisions solely on the raft.
He expressed hope that the men searching for them had found the decoy campfire he built and wasted the night watching it for Jim.
Huck felt a sense of accomplishment, believing that even if his deception didn't entirely fool the pursuers, he had done his utmost to mislead them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It must a been close on to one o’clock when we got below the island at last, and the raft did seem to go mighty slow.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I played it as low down on them as I could.

events.text_segment:
It must a been close on to one o’clock when we got below the island at last, and the raft did seem to go mighty slow. If a boat was to come along we was going to take to the canoe and break for the Illinois shore; and it was well a boat didn’t come, for we hadn’t ever thought to put the gun in the canoe, or a fishing-line, or anything to eat. We was in ruther too much of a sweat to think of so many things. It warn’t good judgment to put everything on the raft.
If the men went to the island I just expect they found the camp fire I built, and watched it all night for Jim to come. Anyways, they stayed away from us, and if my building the fire never fooled them it warn’t no fault of mine. I played it as low down on them as I could.

It must a been close on to one o'clock when we got below the island at last, and the raft did seem to go mighty slow. If a boat was to come along, we was going to take to the canoe and break for the Illinois shore; and it was well a boat didn't come, for we hadn't ever thought to put the gun in the canoe, or a fishing-line, or anything to eat. We was in rather too much of a sweat to think of so many things. It warn't good judgment to put everything on the raft.

If them men had got ahold of the raft they would've found the fire I built, and that would've fetched them sure. I was mighty glad they didn't come prowling around. I reckon they'd wasted the whole night up there watching my camp-fire, waiting for Jim to come. Anyways, if they didn't get him, it wasn't no fault of mine. I done my level best to throw them off the scent, and I couldn't a done no more if I'd a studied it a year.

events.title: Securing a Hiding Spot and Reflecting on Pursuit
detailed_summary: At first light, Huck and Jim concealed their raft by covering it with cottonwood branches on a tow-head (a sandbar with trees) along the Illinois shore, making it appear like a natural bank collapse.
They felt secure due to their location, with mountains on the Missouri side, dense woods on the Illinois side, and the main river channel running along the Missouri shore.
They spent the entire day hidden, observing the river traffic, including rafts and steamboats.
Huck recounted his conversation with Mrs. Judith Loftus to Jim.
Jim remarked on Mrs. Loftus's cleverness, suggesting she would be smart enough to use a dog to track them rather than just watch a campfire.
Huck then questioned why she hadn't advised her husband to get a dog immediately.
Jim surmised that she likely thought of it later, and the delay caused by the men needing to go to town for a dog gave Huck and Jim the time needed to escape much farther downriver.
Huck concluded that the specific reasons for their successful evasion were less important than the fact that they had, indeed, escaped capture.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the first streak of day began to show we tied up to a tow-head in a big bend on the Illinois side, and hacked off cottonwood branches with the hatchet, and covered up the raft with them so she looked like there had been a cave-in in the bank there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I said I didn’t care what was the reason they didn’t get us as long as they didn’t.

events.text_segment:
When the first streak of day began to show we tied up to a tow-head in a big bend on the Illinois side, and hacked off cottonwood branches with the hatchet, and covered up the raft with them so she looked like there had been a cave-in in the bank there. A tow-head is a sandbar that has cottonwoods on it as thick as harrow-teeth.
We had mountains on the Missouri shore and heavy timber on the Illinois side, and the channel was down the Missouri shore at that place, so we warn’t afraid of anybody running across us. We laid there all day, and watched the rafts and steamboats spin down the Missouri shore, and up-bound steamboats fight the big river in the middle. I told Jim all about the time I had jabbering with that woman; and Jim said she was a smart one, and if she was to start after us herself she wouldn’t set down and watch a camp fire—no, sir, she’d fetch a dog. Well, then, I said, why couldn’t she tell her husband to fetch a dog? Jim said he bet she did think of it by the time the men was ready to start, and he believed they must a gone up-town to get a dog and so they lost all that time, or else we wouldn’t be here on a tow-head sixteen or seventeen mile below the village—no, indeedy, we would be in that same old town again. So I said I didn’t care what was the reason they didn’t get us as long as they didn’t.

Jim said he bet she did think of it by the time the men was ready to start, and he believed they must a gone up-town to get a dog and so they lost all that time, or else we wouldn't be here on this tow-head sixteen or seventeen mile below the village—no, indeedy, we would be in that same old town again. So I said I didn't care what was the reason they didn't get us as long as they didn't.

events.title: Improving the Raft for the Journey
detailed_summary: As evening approached, Huck and Jim checked their surroundings from their hiding spot and saw no one.
Jim then constructed a cozy shelter, or wigwam, on the raft using some of its top planks, designed to offer protection from sun and rain and to keep their supplies dry.
He elevated the wigwam's floor about a foot above the raft's deck to safeguard their blankets and other items from waves created by steamboats.
Inside the wigwam, they created a fire pit using a layer of dirt held by a frame, enabling them to have a concealed fire during inclement or cold weather.
They also crafted a spare steering oar, anticipating that one of their existing oars might break.

Additionally, they prepared a forked stick to hang their lantern, which was essential for signaling downstream steamboats to prevent collisions, though it wasn't always necessary for upstream boats unless they were at a river crossing, because the high water levels allowed upstream vessels to navigate outside the main channel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When it was beginning to come on dark we poked our heads out of the cottonwood thicket, and looked up and down and across; nothing in sight; so Jim took up some of the top planks of the raft and built a snug wigwam to get under in blazing weather and rainy, and to keep the things dry.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We fixed up a short forked stick to hang the old lantern on, because we must always light the lantern whenever we see a steamboat coming down-stream, to keep from getting run over; but we wouldn’t have to light it for up-stream boats unless we see we was in what they call a “crossing”; for the river was pretty high yet, very low banks being still a little under water; so up-bound boats didn’t always run the channel, but hunted easy water.

events.text_segment: When it was beginning to come on dark we poked our heads out of the cottonwood thicket, and looked up and down and across; nothing in sight; so Jim took up some of the top planks of the raft and built a snug wigwam to get under in blazing weather and rainy, and to keep the things dry. Jim made a floor for the wigwam, and raised it a foot or more above the level of the raft, so now the blankets and all the traps was out of reach of steamboat waves. Right in the middle of the wigwam we made a layer of dirt about five or six inches deep with a frame around it for to hold it to its place; this was to build a fire on in sloppy weather or chilly; the wigwam would keep it from being seen. We made an extra steering-oar, too, because one of the others might get broke on a snag or something. We fixed up a short forked stick to hang the old lantern on, because we must always light the lantern whenever we see a steamboat coming down-stream, to keep from getting run over; but we wouldn’t have to light it for up-stream boats unless we see we was in what they call a “crossing”; for the river was pretty high yet, very low banks being still a little under water; so up-bound boats didn’t always run the channel, but hunted easy water.

events.title: Peaceful Nights on the River and Passing St. Louis
detailed_summary: On their second night after leaving the tow-head, they traveled for seven to eight hours, propelled by a current moving over four miles an hour.
Their journey was filled with activities like fishing, conversation, and occasional swims to ward off drowsiness.
Drifting down the vast, silent river while gazing at the stars evoked a solemn mood, leading them to speak softly and laugh infrequently, usually with only a quiet chuckle.
They generally experienced favorable weather and encountered no significant problems for several consecutive nights.
Each night they passed towns, which appeared as distant clusters of lights on dark hillsides, with no individual houses discernible.
On their fifth night, they passed St. Louis, which seemed like an entire world illuminated.

Huck, who had previously doubted St. Petersburg claims about St. Louis's population of twenty to thirty thousand, found himself believing it upon seeing the magnificent expanse of lights at two in the morning.
The city was completely silent, its inhabitants seemingly all asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This second night we run between seven and eight hours, with a current that was making over four mile an hour.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There warn’t a sound there; everybody was asleep.

events.text_segment:
This second night we run between seven and eight hours, with a current that was making over four mile an hour. We catched fish and talked, and we took a swim now and then to keep off sleepiness. It was kind of solemn, drifting down the big, still river, laying on our backs looking up at the stars, and we didn’t ever feel like talking loud, and it warn’t often that we laughed—only a little kind of a low chuckle. We had mighty good weather as a general thing, and nothing ever happened to us at all—that night, nor the next, nor the next.
Every night we passed towns, some of them away up on black hillsides, nothing but just a shiny bed of lights; not a house could you see. The fifth night we passed St. Louis, and it was like the whole world lit up. In St. Petersburg they used to say there was twenty or thirty thousand people in St. Louis, but I never believed it till I see that wonderful spread of lights at two o’clock that still night. There warn’t a sound there; everybody was asleep.

This second night we run between seven and eight hours, with a current that was making over four mile an hour. The raft was moving along right smart, and we kept ourselves busy with fishing, and swimming now and then to keep awake, and talking about all manner of things.

There's something mighty peaceful about floating down the big river at night. Jim and me would lay on our backs and look up at the stars, and it was like we was the only souls in the whole world. We didn't talk loud—just sort of quiet-like—and when we laughed, it wasn't no regular laugh, but just a little soft chuckle that didn't seem to disturb nothing.

"Huck," Jim would say, looking up at them stars scattered all across the sky, "you reckon dem stars was made or just happened?"

I'd study on it a while, watching the reflection of them stars dancing on the water. "I don't rightly know, Jim. They're awful far away, ain't they?"

The weather held good for us night after night. We didn't run into no trouble worth mentioning. Every night we'd pass towns—you couldn't see no houses, just clusters of lights on the dark hills, like somebody had dropped a handful of fireflies there.

The fifth night we passed St. Louis, and I tell you it was a sight to see. It looked like the whole world was lit up. I remembered how folks in St. Petersburg used to talk about St. Louis having twenty or thirty thousand people living there, and I always thought they was stretching it. But seeing all them lights spread out for miles at two in the morning, with not a sound coming from it—everybody sleeping—I reckoned it must be true after all.
```

events.title: Foraging for Supplies and Moral Negotiations
detailed_summary: Huck established a nightly routine of going ashore near small villages around 10 p.m. to purchase about ten or fifteen cents' worth of food like meal or bacon.

Occasionally, he would also steal a chicken, justifying this with his father's saying that one should take a chicken when possible, as it could be a good deed if someone else needed it, though Huck noted his father always wanted the chicken for himself.
In the early mornings, before daylight, Huck would 'borrow' produce like watermelons, muskmelons, pumpkins, or new corn from fields.

Huck recalled his Pap's philosophy that 'borrowing' items was not harmful if one intended to return them eventually, contrasting this with the Widow Douglas's view that it was merely a euphemism for stealing and something no decent person would do.

Jim suggested a compromise, opining that both Pap and the Widow were partially correct. He proposed they select a few items from their 'borrowing' list and agree not to take those anymore, which he reasoned would make it morally acceptable to 'borrow' the other items.
After discussing the matter throughout one night as they drifted down the river, they reached a satisfactory decision to stop 'borrowing' crabapples and persimmons.
Huck felt relieved and pleased with this outcome, particularly since crabapples were not very good, and persimmons wouldn't be ripe for several months.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Every night now I used to slip ashore towards ten o’clock at some little village, and buy ten or fifteen cents’ worth of meal or bacon or other stuff to eat; and sometimes I lifted a chicken that warn’t roosting comfortable, and took him along.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I was glad the way it come out, too, because crabapples ain’t ever good, and the p’simmons wouldn’t be ripe for two or three months yet.

events.text_segment:
Every night now I used to slip ashore towards ten o’clock at some little village, and buy ten or fifteen cents’ worth of meal or bacon or other stuff to eat; and sometimes I lifted a chicken that warn’t roosting comfortable, and took him along. Pap always said, take a chicken when you get a chance, because if you don’t want him yourself you can easy find somebody that does, and a good deed ain’t ever forgot. I never see pap when he didn’t want the chicken himself, but that is what he used to say, anyway.
Mornings before daylight I slipped into cornfields and borrowed a watermelon, or a mushmelon, or a punkin, or some new corn, or things of that kind. Pap always said it warn’t no harm to borrow things if you was meaning to pay them back some time; but the widow said it warn’t anything but a soft name for stealing, and no decent body would do it. Jim said he reckoned the widow was partly right and pap was partly right; so the best way would be for us to pick out two or three things from the list and say we wouldn’t borrow them any more—then he reckoned it wouldn’t be no harm to borrow the others. So we talked it over all one night, drifting along down the river, trying to make up our minds whether to drop the watermelons, or the cantelopes, or the mushmelons, or what. But towards daylight we got it all settled satisfactory, and concluded to drop crabapples and p’simmons. We warn’t feeling just right before that, but it was all comfortable now. I was glad the way it come out, too, because crabapples ain’t ever good, and the p’simmons wouldn’t be ripe for two or three months yet.

Before daylight we would be going on with our trip, and I'd slip ashore in the early morning and pick up a watermelon, or a mushmelon, or a punkin, or some new corn, or things of that kind. According to her, there warn't no such thing as waste - everything belonged to somebody, and you had no right taking it without asking.

Jim and me, we got along mighty well on the raft. He'd got to trusting me more and more, and we'd set and talk about old times on the river, and I'd see him getting cheerful again. He said he'd rather be a free man on a raft with a friend than be rich and living in houses with people that didn't care about him.

events.title: Discovery of the Wrecked Steamboat and Huck's Insistence on Exploring
detailed_summary: Huck and Jim occasionally supplemented their provisions by shooting waterfowl, contributing to their relatively comfortable existence on the raft.
Five nights after passing St. Louis, they encountered a violent thunderstorm after midnight, characterized by powerful thunder, lightning, and torrential rain.
They took refuge in their wigwam, allowing the raft to drift at the mercy of the storm.
During flashes of lightning, they observed that they were on a broad, straight section of the river, flanked by high, rocky bluffs.
Huck suddenly spotted a steamboat that had wrecked on a rock, lying directly in their path.

The lightning illuminated the wreck distinctly, revealing it leaning over with part of its upper deck above water, and details such as its chimney supports and a chair by the main bell with an old hat hanging on it.
The eerie and solitary sight of the wreck in the stormy darkness stirred Huck's adventurous instincts, making him eager to board and explore it.
He proposed to Jim that they land on the steamboat.
Jim was initially strongly against the idea, citing fear, biblical caution against tempting fate, and the potential presence of a watchman.

Huck dismissed Jim's concerns, arguing that no one would risk their life guarding a wreck on such a perilous night, and highlighted the possibility of finding valuable items like cigars in the captain's quarters.
He invoked Tom Sawyer, asserting that Tom would view it as an adventure and seize the opportunity to explore, and would do so with characteristic flair and style.
Huck expressed a wish for Tom Sawyer's presence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We shot a water-fowl, now and then, that got up too early in the morning or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I wish Tom Sawyer was here.”

events.text_segment:
We shot a water-fowl, now and then, that got up too early in the morning or didn’t go to bed early enough in the evening. Take it all round, we lived pretty high.
The fifth night below St. Louis we had a big storm after midnight, with a power of thunder and lightning, and the rain poured down in a solid sheet. We stayed in the wigwam and let the raft take care of itself. When the lightning glared out we could see a big straight river ahead, and high, rocky bluffs on both sides. By-and-by says I, “Hel-lo, Jim, looky yonder!” It was a steamboat that had killed herself on a rock. We was drifting straight down for her. The lightning showed her very distinct. She was leaning over, with part of her upper deck above water, and you could see every little chimbly-guy clean and clear, and a chair by the big bell, with an old slouch hat hanging on the back of it, when the flashes come.
Well, it being away in the night and stormy, and all so mysterious-like, I felt just the way any other boy would a felt when I see that wreck laying there so mournful and lonesome in the middle of the river. I wanted to get aboard of her and slink around a little, and see what there was there. So I says:
“Le’s land on her, Jim.”
But Jim was dead against it at first. He says:
“I doan’ want to go fool’n ’long er no wrack. We’s doin’ blame’ well, en we better let blame’ well alone, as de good book says. Like as not dey’s a watchman on dat wrack.”
“Watchman your grandmother,” I says; “there ain’t nothing to watch but the texas and the pilot-house; and do you reckon anybody’s going to resk his life for a texas and a pilot-house such a night as this, when it’s likely to break up and wash off down the river any minute?” Jim couldn’t say nothing to that, so he didn’t try. “And besides,” I says, “we might borrow something worth having out of the captain’s stateroom. Seegars, I bet you—and cost five cents apiece, solid cash. Steamboat captains is always rich, and get sixty dollars a month, and they don’t care a cent what a thing costs, you know, long as they want it. Stick a candle in your pocket; I can’t rest, Jim, till we give her a rummaging. Do you reckon Tom Sawyer would ever go by this thing? Not for pie, he wouldn’t. He’d call it an adventure—that’s what he’d call it; and he’d land on that wreck if it was his last act. And wouldn’t he throw style into it?—wouldn’t he spread himself, nor nothing? Why, you’d think it was Christopher C’lumbus discovering Kingdom-Come. I wish Tom Sawyer was here.”

events.title: Boarding the Wreck and Eavesdropping on a Confrontation
detailed_summary: Jim, though grumbling, conceded to Huck's plan to explore the wreck, on the condition that they minimize their conversation and speak very softly.
A fortunate lightning flash illuminated their path, allowing them to reach the starboard derrick of the wreck and secure their raft.
The steamboat's deck was considerably higher than their raft.
They moved cautiously in the darkness along the sloping deck towards the texas (officers' cabins), using their feet to feel the way and their hands to avoid obstructions.
Upon reaching the forward end of the skylight, they climbed onto it, which brought them near the captain's open cabin door.
Unexpectedly, they saw a light emanating from further down the texas hall and, at the same moment, heard low voices.
Jim whispered to Huck that he felt very ill and urged him to return to the raft.
Huck agreed and was about to leave, but then he heard a voice desperately pleading not to be harmed and promising never to reveal anything.

A second, louder voice responded, accusing the first speaker, identified as Jim Turner, of being a liar who consistently manipulated situations to get more than his share by threatening to inform on others, declaring that Turner had finally overplayed his hand and was the most despicable and treacherous person in the region.

“It’s a lie, Jim Turner. You’ve acted this way before. You always want more’n your share of the truck, and you’ve always got it, too, because you’ve swore ’t if you didn’t you’d tell. But this time you’ve said it jest one time too many. You’re the meanest, treacherousest hound in this country.”

events.text_segment:
Jim he grumbled a little, but give in. He said we mustn’t talk any more than we could help, and then talk mighty low. The lightning showed us the wreck again just in time, and we fetched the stabboard derrick, and made fast there.
The deck was high out here. We went sneaking down the slope of it to labboard, in the dark, towards the texas, feeling our way slow with our feet, and spreading our hands out to fend off the guys, for it was so dark we couldn’t see no sign of them. Pretty soon we struck the forward end of the skylight, and clumb on to it; and the next step fetched us in front of the captain’s door, which was open, and by Jimminy, away down through the texas-hall we see a light! and all in the same second we seem to hear low voices in yonder!
Jim whispered and said he was feeling powerful sick, and told me to come along. I says, all right, and was going to start for the raft; but just then I heard a voice wail out and say:
“Oh, please don’t, boys; I swear I won’t ever tell!”
Another voice said, pretty loud:
“It’s a lie, Jim Turner. You’ve acted this way before. You always want more’n your share of the truck, and you’ve always got it, too, because you’ve swore ’t if you didn’t you’d tell. But this time you’ve said it jest one time too many. You’re the meanest, treacherousest hound in this country.”

Jim he grumbled a little, but give in. He whispered that we ought to promise not to talk any, and that we must keep mighty quiet. I told him I would, and we set off toward the wreck.

Just then the night lit up with a flash of lightning, and we could see our way. We made it to the wreck's starboard side and tied our raft to the derrick. The deck was standing pretty high above us. We had to feel our way along in the dark, stepping careful on the sloping deck, using our hands to keep from bumping into things.

We worked our way toward the texas, and after a while we got to the forward end of the skylight. From there we climbed up where we could almost reach the captain's door, which was standing open.

Then something caught my eye - a light showing further down the texas. And right at the same moment, we heard voices talking low.

Jim grabbed my arm and whispered, "Oh, Huck, I don't feel good. I'm powerful sick. We better get back to the raft."

I was just about to agree when I heard somebody saying in a begging voice, "Please don't, boys; I swear I won't ever tell."

Another voice, much rougher, answered back, "It's all lies, Jim Turner! You've always been threatening to tell if you didn't get more than your share. You're the meanest, most treacherous hound in this country, and you've pushed your luck too far this time."
```

events.title: Overhearing a Murderous Plot
detailed_summary: While Huck listened intently, Jim had already retreated towards their raft.
Huck, consumed by curiosity and inspired by what he imagined Tom Sawyer would do, resolved to investigate the situation further.
He crept quietly on his hands and knees through the dark passage until only one stateroom was between him and the cross-hall of the texas.
Peeking in, he saw a man, Jim Turner, tied hand and foot on the floor. Two other men, Bill and Jake Packard, stood over him; Packard held a dim lantern, while Bill brandished a pistol.
Bill repeatedly aimed the pistol at Turner's head, calling him a vile person.
The bound man, Turner, pleaded with Bill not to shoot, promising he would never tell.

Each time Turner begged, Jake Packard, holding the lantern, would laugh derisively, sarcastically agreeing that Turner indeed wouldn't tell, and remarked that Turner would have killed both of them if they hadn't overpowered him, merely for asserting their rights. Packard then instructed Bill to lower the pistol.
Bill expressed his reluctance, stating his intent to kill Turner, referencing Turner's past actions, like killing an 'old Hatfield,' and arguing Turner deserved death.
Packard responded that he did not want Turner killed and had his own reasons for this.
This statement elicited a tearful expression of gratitude from the man on the floor.

Ignoring Turner's outburst, Packard hung his lantern on a nail and began moving towards Huck's hiding spot, signaling Bill to accompany him. Huck quickly crawled backward but, hindered by the boat's slant, ducked into an empty stateroom and concealed himself in an upper berth.

Packard and Bill entered the stateroom where Huck was hidden; he could smell the whisky they had been drinking. Terrified, Huck held his breath, barely able to listen to their hushed, serious conversation.
Bill argued that Turner would certainly inform on them if given the chance and insisted on killing him to ensure their safety.
To Bill's initial surprise, Packard quietly agreed with the sentiment.

However, Packard then elaborated, suggesting a 'quieter' method: they would first search the staterooms for any remaining valuables, take the loot ashore, and hide it. He predicted the wreck would break apart and be washed downriver within two hours, which would result in Turner drowning.
Packard presented this as a preferable alternative to actively killing Turner, framing it as more sensible and morally superior, as it avoided direct responsibility for Turner's death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By this time Jim was gone for the raft.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ain’t I right?”

events.text_segment:
By this time Jim was gone for the raft. I was just a-biling with curiosity; and I says to myself, Tom Sawyer wouldn’t back out now, and so I won’t either; I’m a-going to see what’s going on here. So I dropped on my hands and knees in the little passage, and crept aft in the dark till there warn’t but one stateroom betwixt me and the cross-hall of the texas. Then in there I see a man stretched on the floor and tied hand and foot, and two men standing over him, and one of them had a dim lantern in his hand, and the other one had a pistol. This one kept pointing the pistol at the man’s head on the floor, and saying:
“I’d like to! And I orter, too—a mean skunk!”
The man on the floor would shrivel up and say, “Oh, please don’t, Bill; I hain’t ever goin’ to tell.”
And every time he said that the man with the lantern would laugh and say:
“’Deed you ain’t! You never said no truer thing ’n that, you bet you.” And once he said: “Hear him beg! and yit if we hadn’t got the best of him and tied him he’d a killed us both. And what for? Jist for noth’n. Jist because we stood on our rights—that’s what for. But I lay you ain’t a-goin’ to threaten nobody any more, Jim Turner. Put up that pistol, Bill.”
Bill says:
“I don’t want to, Jake Packard. I’m for killin’ him—and didn’t he kill old Hatfield jist the same way—and don’t he deserve it?”
“But I don’t want him killed, and I’ve got my reasons for it.”
“Bless yo’ heart for them words, Jake Packard! I’ll never forgit you long’s I live!” says the man on the floor, sort of blubbering.
Packard didn’t take no notice of that, but hung up his lantern on a nail and started towards where I was there in the dark, and motioned Bill to come. I crawfished as fast as I could about two yards, but the boat slanted so that I couldn’t make very good time; so to keep from getting run over and catched I crawled into a stateroom on the upper side. The man came a-pawing along in the dark, and when Packard got to my stateroom, he says:
“Here—come in here.”
And in he come, and Bill after him. But before they got in I was up in the upper berth, cornered, and sorry I come. Then they stood there, with their hands on the ledge of the berth, and talked. I couldn’t see them, but I could tell where they was by the whisky they’d been having. I was glad I didn’t drink whisky; but it wouldn’t made much difference anyway, because most of the time they couldn’t a treed me because I didn’t breathe. I was too scared. And, besides, a body couldn’t breathe and hear such talk. They talked low and earnest. Bill wanted to kill Turner. He says:
“He’s said he’ll tell, and he will. If we was to give both our shares to him now it wouldn’t make no difference after the row and the way we’ve served him. Shore’s you’re born, he’ll turn State’s evidence; now you hear me. I’m for putting him out of his troubles.”
“So’m I,” says Packard, very quiet.
“Blame it, I’d sorter begun to think you wasn’t. Well, then, that’s all right. Le’s go and do it.”
“Hold on a minute; I hain’t had my say yit. You listen to me. Shooting’s good, but there’s quieter ways if the thing’s got to be done. But what I say is this: it ain’t good sense to go court’n around after a halter if you can git at what you’re up to in some way that’s jist as good and at the same time don’t bring you into no resks. Ain’t that so?”
“You bet it is. But how you goin’ to manage it this time?”
“Well, my idea is this: we’ll rustle around and gather up whatever pickins we’ve overlooked in the staterooms, and shove for shore and hide the truck. Then we’ll wait. Now I say it ain’t a-goin’ to be more’n two hours befo’ this wrack breaks up and washes off down the river. See? He’ll be drownded, and won’t have nobody to blame for it but his own self. I reckon that’s a considerble sight better ’n killin’ of him. I’m unfavorable to killin’ a man as long as you can git aroun’ it; it ain’t good sense, it ain’t good morals. Ain’t I right?”

And in he come, and Bill after him. But before they got in I was up in the upper berth, cornered, and sorry I come. Then they stood there, with their hands on the ledge of the berth, and talked. I couldn't see them, but I could tell where they was by the whisky they'd been having. I was glad I didn't drink whisky; but it wouldn't made much difference anyway, because they didn't know I was in there, and I had a good place to hide and keep quiet. I was trembling, because I had to cough, and yet I didn't dare to.

There was a long quiet, and then Bill says:

"He'll turn state's evidence, that's what he'll do. Now you hear me. I'm for putting him out of his troubles right off. He's said he'll tell, and he will."

"So'm I," says Packard, very quiet.

"Blame it, I'd sorter begun to think you wasn't. Well, then, that's all right. Let's go and do it."

"Hold on a minute; I hain't had my say yit. You listen to me. Shooting's good, but there's quieter ways if the thing's got to be done. But what I say is this: it ain't good sense to go court'n around after a halter if you can git at what you're up to in some way that's jist as good and at the same time don't bring you into no resks. Ain't that so?"

"You bet it is. But how you goin' to manage it this time?"

"Well, my idea is this: we'll rustle around and gather up whatever pickins we've overlooked in the staterooms, and shove for shore and hide the truck. Then we'll wait. Now I say it ain't a-goin' to be more'n two hours befo' this wrack breaks up and washes off down the river. See? He'll be drownded, and won't have nobody to blame for it but his own self. I reckon that's a considerble sight better 'n killin' of him. I'm unfavorable to killin' a man as long as you can git aroun' it; it ain't good sense, it ain't good morals. Ain't I right?"
```

events.title: Huck's Desperate Plan and a Shocking Discovery
detailed_summary: Bill questioned Jake Packard's plan, asking what they would do if the steamboat wreck didn't break apart and wash away as Packard anticipated.
Packard suggested they could simply wait the two hours to see what happened, and Bill agreed to this course of action.
As Packard and Bill departed, Huck, drenched in a cold sweat from fear, quickly scrambled from his hiding place and hurried forward in the pitch-dark conditions.
He whispered for Jim, and Jim responded with a moan from close by.

Huck urgently informed Jim that there was no time for moaning, as a group of murderers was on the wreck. He proposed they find the murderers' boat and set it adrift down the river. This would prevent the gang from escaping the wreck, thereby ensuring that one of them (Jim Turner) would be in grave danger.
Huck elaborated that if they successfully set the criminals' boat adrift, all of them would be in a dire situation, as the Sheriff would then be able to apprehend them.
He directed Jim to search one side of the wreck for the boat while he searched the other, starting their search from where their own raft was moored.
Jim, in great distress, cried out that their raft was no longer there; it had broken loose and drifted away, leaving them stranded on the wrecked steamboat.

“Yes, I reck’n you are. But s’pose she don’t break up and wash off?”
“Well, we can wait the two hours anyway and see, can’t we?”
“All right, then; come along.”
So they started, and I lit out, all in a cold sweat, and scrambled forward. It was dark as pitch there; but I said, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “Jim!” and he answered up, right at my elbow, with a sort of a moan, and I says:
“Quick, Jim, it ain’t no time for fooling around and moaning; there’s a gang of murderers in yonder, and if we don’t hunt up their boat and set her drifting down the river so these fellows can’t get away from the wreck there’s one of ’em going to be in a bad fix. But if we find their boat we can put all of ’em in a bad fix—for the Sheriff ’ll get ’em. Quick—hurry! I’ll hunt the labboard side, you hunt the stabboard. You start at the raft, and—”
“Oh, my lordy, lordy! Raf’? Dey ain’ no raf’ no mo’; she done broke loose en gone I—en here we is!”

events.title: Perilous Escape from the Wreck
detailed_summary: Huck is initially overcome with fear at being trapped on a wrecked steamboat with a dangerous gang, but recognizes the urgent need to acquire their boat for his and Jim's survival.
He and Jim, who is extremely frightened and weak, nervously make their way along the steamboat's side towards the stern in search of the boat.
They eventually locate the skiff near the cross-hall door, filling Huck with immense gratitude.
Just as Huck is about to board the skiff, one of the gang members, Packard, emerges and instructs his accomplice, Bill, to conceal their lantern.
Packard and Bill then board the skiff themselves.
Bill inquires if Packard has searched their captive, Jim Turner, for his share of money.
Discovering that neither of them has secured Turner's cash, they decide it's essential to retrieve it before leaving, deeming it foolish to abandon the money.
The two men re-enter the cabin on the wreck.
The door slams shut due to the boat's tilted position, providing Huck and Jim with a critical opportunity.
Huck immediately jumps into the skiff, followed by Jim, and Huck quickly cuts the rope, allowing them to drift away silently.

Once they are a safe distance from the wreck, they observe a lantern light briefly appear at the texas door, signaling that the robbers have discovered their boat is missing and are now in a dire situation themselves.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When we was three or four hundred yards down-stream we see the lantern show like a little spark at the texas door for a second, and we knowed by that that the rascals had missed their boat, and was beginning to understand that they was in just as much trouble now as Jim Turner was.

events.text_segment:
Well, I catched my breath and most fainted. Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that! But it warn’t no time to be sentimentering. We’d got to find that boat now—had to have it for ourselves. So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, too—seemed a week before we got to the stern. No sign of a boat. Jim said he didn’t believe he could go any further—so scared he hadn’t hardly any strength left, he said. But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure. So on we prowled again. We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water. When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough! I could just barely see her. I felt ever so thankful. In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened. One of the men stuck his head out only about a couple of foot from me, and I thought I was gone; but he jerked it in again, and says:
“Heave that blame lantern out o’ sight, Bill!”
He flung a bag of something into the boat, and then got in himself and set down. It was Packard. Then Bill he come out and got in. Packard says, in a low voice:
“All ready—shove off!”
I couldn’t hardly hang on to the shutters, I was so weak. But Bill says:
“Hold on—’d you go through him?”
“No. Didn’t you?”
“No. So he’s got his share o’ the cash yet.”
“Well, then, come along; no use to take truck and leave money.”
“Say, won’t he suspicion what we’re up to?”
“Maybe he won’t. But we got to have it anyway. Come along.”
So they got out and went in.
The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me. I out with my knife and cut the rope, and away we went!
We didn’t touch an oar, and we didn’t speak nor whisper, nor hardly even breathe. We went gliding swift along, dead silent, past the tip of the paddle-box, and past the stern; then in a second or two more we was a hundred yards below the wreck, and the darkness soaked her up, every last sign of her, and we was safe, and knowed it.
When we was three or four hundred yards down-stream we see the lantern show like a little spark at the texas door for a second, and we knowed by that that the rascals had missed their boat, and was beginning to understand that they was in just as much trouble now as Jim Turner was.

events.title: Huck's Conscience and Foiled Rescue Plan
detailed_summary: As Jim rows them away from the wreck and towards their own raft, Huck begins to feel uneasy about the fate of the men left behind, even though they are murderers.
He reflects on the dreadful predicament of the robbers and considers that he himself might one day commit a similar crime, prompting empathy.

Huck devises a plan and explains it to Jim: they will land near the first light they spot, find a hiding place for Jim and the skiff, and then Huck will invent a story to persuade someone to rescue the gang from the wreck, with the ultimate intention that they can be properly arrested and hanged.
This plan is quickly thwarted as a severe storm erupts, making it impossible to see any lights, as everyone is presumed to be indoors.
They continue their journey downriver, keeping a lookout for any signs of light or their raft.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft.

events.text_segment:
Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft. Now was the first time that I begun to worry about the men—I reckon I hadn’t had time to before. I begun to think how dreadful it was, even for murderers, to be in such a fix. I says to myself, there ain’t no telling but I might come to be a murderer myself yet, and then how would I like it? So says I to Jim:
“The first light we see we’ll land a hundred yards below it or above it, in a place where it’s a good hiding-place for you and the skiff, and then I’ll go and fix up some kind of a yarn, and get somebody to go for that gang and get them out of their scrape, so they can be hung when their time comes.”
But that idea was a failure; for pretty soon it begun to storm again, and this time worse than ever. The rain poured down, and never a light showed; everybody in bed, I reckon. We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft.

We boomed along down the river, watching for lights and watching for our raft. After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by and by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Then Jim manned the oars, and we took out after our raft. When we had made a fair distance, I noticed the fog was lifting. The river was clearing up, and we could see the raft drifting ahead of us. Jim pulled hard on the oars, his muscles straining with each stroke, determined to catch up to our floating home.

"Dah she is!" Jim exclaimed, pointing ahead.

I felt a wave of relief wash over me. We'd been separated from the raft in that thick fog, and I'd feared we might never find it again. The Mississippi was wide and dangerous, especially at night.

As we drew closer, I could make out our belongings still secured on the deck. Nothing seemed to have been disturbed. The river was calm now, almost peaceful compared to earlier when the fog had wrapped around us like a thick blanket.

"We's lucky, Huck," Jim said, breathing hard from rowing. "De good Lord was watchin' over us tonight."

I nodded, though I wasn't sure if it was the Lord or just plain luck. Either way, I was mighty glad to see that raft again.

events.title: Reclaiming the Raft and New Objective
detailed_summary: After a prolonged period, the rain subsides, and intermittent lightning flashes reveal their raft floating ahead, which they quickly head towards.
They are overjoyed to be back aboard their raft.
Shortly thereafter, they observe a light on the shore to their right.
Huck decides he will investigate the light, using the skiff which is laden with plunder the gang had stolen from the wreck.
They hastily transfer the stolen goods from the skiff to a pile on the raft.
Huck instructs Jim to continue floating downstream, to show a light when he estimates he has traveled about two miles, and to keep it burning until Huck's return.
As Huck rows towards the initial light, three or four more lights become visible on a hillside, indicating the presence of a village.
He maneuvers the skiff above the shore light, then stops rowing and allows the current to carry him as he assesses the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I closed in above the shore light, and laid on my oars and floated.

events.text_segment:
After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.
It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again. We seen a light now away down to the right, on shore. So I said I would go for it. The skiff was half full of plunder which that gang had stole there on the wreck. We hustled it on to the raft in a pile, and I told Jim to float along down, and show a light when he judged he had gone about two mile, and keep it burning till I come; then I manned my oars and shoved for the light. As I got down towards it, three or four more showed—up on a hillside. It was a village. I closed in above the shore light, and laid on my oars and floated.

# text_segment

After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.

It was the raft, and mighty glad was we to get aboard of it again. And when we got on it and got our clothes wrung out and our traps all put away, we was pretty tired and sleepy. So Jim he said he would stand the first watch; but he was pretty tired too, so by-and-by I took my turn, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm was over, and Jim was on watch. So I laid down in the canoe and was most ready to drop off to sleep, when I sees a light away down to the right, on shore. I got up and went and roused Jim, and says:

"Gimme the paddle; I'm a-going to see what that light is. It mightn't be nothing but it might."

Jim had the raft fixed so that it was hid, and then we took the canoe and went down there to see what the light was. By-and-by, as we got down towards it three or four more showed—up on a hillside. It was a village. I went down and struck above the village, and hid the canoe, and then I clumb up a tree to see what I could see.

After a long time the rain let up, but the clouds stayed, and the lightning kept whimpering, and by-and-by a flash showed us a black thing ahead, floating, and we made for it.

It was a raft. When we got to it, we saw there was men on it. They were snoring away, all wet and shivery. We paddled around it, quiet-like, and Jim was ready to jump aboard when I whispered, "Better give them a hail first."

It was Buck Grangerford. I knowed him by his voice. And that's how we met up with the feuding families.

events.title: Encountering the Sleeping Watchman
detailed_summary: Huck observes that the light emanates from a lantern on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat.
He searches for the ferry's watchman and finds him asleep, curled up on the bitts at the front of the vessel.
To rouse the watchman, Huck gives his shoulder a couple of gentle shoves and begins to feign crying.
The watchman awakens with a start, but upon seeing it is only Huck, he relaxes, stretches, and inquires about the cause of Huck's supposed distress, advising him not to cry.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I went by, I see it was a lantern hanging on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What’s the matter with ’em?”

events.text_segment:
As I went by, I see it was a lantern hanging on the jackstaff of a double-hull ferry-boat. I skimmed around for the watchman, a-wondering whereabouts he slept; and by-and-by I found him roosting on the bitts, forward, with his head down between his knees. I gave his shoulder two or three little shoves, and begun to cry.
He stirred up, in a kind of a startlish way; but when he see it was only me, he took a good gap and stretch, and then he says:
“Hello, what’s up? Don’t cry, bub. What’s the trouble?”

"Hello, what's up? Don't cry, bub. What's the trouble?"

I says:

I skimmed down along the timber line to watch her. By and by she come along, and she drifted in so close that they could a run out a plank and walked ashore. Most everybody was on the boat.

events.title: Huck Weaves a Tale of Distress
detailed_summary: Huck begins his fabricated story by tearfully mentioning his 'Pap, and mam, and sis,' then breaks off as if overcome by emotion.
The watchman attempts to console him, remarking that troubles are a common part of life and that this situation will likely resolve itself.
Huck confirms that the man is indeed the watchman of the boat.

The watchman proudly elaborates on his multiple roles aboard the ferry, including captain, owner, and pilot, and expresses contentment with his life compared to that of a wealthy local man named Jim Hornback.
Huck interrupts to declare that his family and a 'Miss Hooker' are in grave danger.
He specifies they are on the 'Walter Scott' wreck, shocking the watchman, who asks how they ended up there.

Huck launches into an elaborate, fictional account: Miss Hooker was visiting Booth's Landing and, while attempting to cross the river by horse-ferry with her servant to visit a friend, they lost their steering-oar.
He claims their ferry then drifted, collided with the wreck, and resulted in the loss of the ferryman, the servant, and the horses, with only Miss Hooker managing to scramble aboard the wreck.
Huck continues that his family's trading-scow later struck the same wreck in the darkness; all were saved except for a beloved crewman named Bill Whipple.

He explains that their cries for help went unheard due to the river's width, so he, being the only swimmer, was dispatched to seek aid, with Miss Hooker instructing him to find her uncle if other help failed.
Huck claims he has been trying to get assistance but has been unsuccessful due to the bad weather and strong current, and now he is pleading with the watchman.
