LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Says I to myself, here's a boy that most everybody in this town has treated like they wished he was dead and done for, and don't care nothing about him, nor what becomes of him, and as soon as he's goin' to be a little bit of trouble, or cost his uncle a cent, why, they're ready to get red of him, and let him go off down the river, maybe to get drowned or something. It's a hard world, that's what it is. Here's Aunt Sally, she'd cry to think I was lost in the river, but she'd get over it quick enough with a new bonnet or some such truck. And Tom Sawyer, he'd make a big adventure out of it, but then go back to his comfortable home with Aunt Polly fussing over him. Even Jim, who I know cares for me true, he's got his own troubles, being a runaway and all. Sometimes I reckon it ain't no use for me to try and be good or do right; seems like nobody notices except when I do wrong. But then I remember how the Widow Douglas tried to sivilize me, and I feel bad for thinking so low.

events.title: The Funeral Service and the Undertaker's Efficiency
detailed_summary: In the morning, Huck observes the family and the con men, trying to discern if anything unusual has occurred, but finds no clues.
The undertaker arrives and prepares the house for the funeral service, arranging chairs.
Huck notices the coffin lid is undisturbed but dares not check for the money with people around.
Mourners arrive and file past the coffin, with the Wilks girls (referred to as 'beats' and 'girls' by Huck) showing their grief.
The undertaker is described as exceptionally stealthy and efficient, managing the crowd and arrangements silently with nods and gestures.
A poorly performing melodeon is played, and a hymn is sung, which Huck finds unimpressive.
Reverend Hobson begins his sermon, but it's abruptly interrupted by a loud commotion caused by a dog in the cellar.
The undertaker calmly and discreetly slips away to the cellar.
A thwack is heard, followed by silence, and the dog's barking ceases.
The undertaker reappears and whispers to the preacher that the dog had caught a rat, much to the satisfaction and curiosity of the attendees.
This incident elevates the undertaker's reputation among the townspeople.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.

events.text_segment:
When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. There warn’t nobody around but the family and the widow Bartley and our tribe. I watched their faces to see if anything had been happening, but I couldn’t tell.
Towards the middle of the day the undertaker come with his man, and they set the coffin in the middle of the room on a couple of chairs, and then set all our chairs in rows, and borrowed more from the neighbors till the hall and the parlor and the dining-room was full. I see the coffin lid was the way it was before, but I dasn’t go to look in under it, with folks around.
Then the people begun to flock in, and the beats and the girls took seats in the front row at the head of the coffin, and for a half an hour the people filed around slow, in single rank, and looked down at the dead man’s face a minute, and some dropped in a tear, and it was all very still and solemn, only the girls and the beats holding handkerchiefs to their eyes and keeping their heads bent, and sobbing a little. There warn’t no other sound but the scraping of the feet on the floor and blowing noses—because people always blows them more at a funeral than they do at other places except church.
When the place was packed full the undertaker he slid around in his black gloves with his softy soothering ways, putting on the last touches, and getting people and things all ship-shape and comfortable, and making no more sound than a cat. He never spoke; he moved people around, he squeezed in late ones, he opened up passageways, and done it with nods, and signs with his hands. Then he took his place over against the wall. He was the softest, glidingest, stealthiest man I ever see; and there warn’t no more smile to him than there is to a ham.
They had borrowed a melodeum—a sick one; and when everything was ready a young woman set down and worked it, and it was pretty skreeky and colicky, and everybody joined in and sung, and Peter was the only one that had a good thing, according to my notion. Then the Reverend Hobson opened up, slow and solemn, and begun to talk; and straight off the most outrageous row busted out in the cellar a body ever heard; it was only one dog, but he made a most powerful racket, and he kept it up right along; the parson he had to stand there, over the coffin, and wait—you couldn’t hear yourself think. It was right down awkward, and nobody didn’t seem to know what to do. But pretty soon they see that long-legged undertaker make a sign to the preacher as much as to say, “Don’t you worry—just depend on me.” Then he stooped down and begun to glide along the wall, just his shoulders showing over the people’s heads. So he glided along, and the powwow and racket getting more and more outrageous all the time; and at last, when he had gone around two sides of the room, he disappears down cellar. Then in about two seconds we heard a whack, and the dog he finished up with a most amazing howl or two, and then everything was dead still, and the parson begun his solemn talk where he left off. In a minute or two here comes this undertaker’s back and shoulders gliding along the wall again; and so he glided and glided around three sides of the room, and then rose up, and shaded his mouth with his hands, and stretched his neck out towards the preacher, over the people’s heads, and says, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “He had a rat!” Then he drooped down and glided along the wall again to his place. You could see it was a great satisfaction to the people, because naturally they wanted to know. A little thing like that don’t cost nothing, and it’s just the little things that makes a man to be looked up to and liked. There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.

events.title: Coffin Sealed and Huck's Renewed Anxiety
detailed_summary: The funeral sermon is lengthy, followed by some typical insincere pronouncements from the King.
Huck becomes anxious as the undertaker approaches the coffin with a screwdriver.
The undertaker seals the coffin lid without incident, leaving Huck uncertain whether the money is still inside or if someone else has taken it.
Huck contemplates the predicament: if he writes to Mary Jane and the money isn't there, she'll think poorly of him.
He concludes it's best to remain silent and not contact Mary Jane, feeling he has only made the situation worse with his attempts to help.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; I’d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thing’s awful mixed now; trying to better it, I’ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness I’d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!

events.text_segment: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I was in a sweat then, and watched him pretty keen. But he never meddled at all; just slid the lid along as soft as mush, and screwed it down tight and fast. So there I was! I didn’t know whether the money was in there or not. So, says I, s’pose somebody has hogged that bag on the sly?—now how do I know whether to write to Mary Jane or not? S’pose she dug him up and didn’t find nothing, what would she think of me? Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; I’d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thing’s awful mixed now; trying to better it, I’ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness I’d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I was getting mighty restless, watching that undertaker work. Every time he turned that screw, it seemed like he was taking forever. The whole church was quiet as a tomb, with nothing but the sound of that screw-driver squeaking. I glanced over at Jim, who was sitting stiff as a board, his eyes wide like he was seeing ghosts.

Then the most awful thing happened. Just as the undertaker was about to seal that coffin for good, there came a scratching sound from inside! Folks gasped and Miss Watson nearly fainted dead away. The king jumped up, hollering about miracles, while the duke went white as a sheet. The preacher started praying loud and fast.

I knew right then we were in for a heap of trouble, because dead folks ain't supposed to scratch.

events.title: The King's Deceptive Plans for the Estate and the Girls
detailed_summary: After Peter Wilks's burial, Huck continues to scrutinize faces for any sign of the money's discovery, but learns nothing.
The King charmingly interacts with everyone, announcing his supposed need to quickly settle the estate and return to his congregation in England.
He proposes taking the Wilks girls with him and his companion, William (the Duke in disguise), to live among their English relatives.
This news delights everyone, especially the girls, who are so pleased they forget their recent sorrow and readily agree to a swift sale of the property.
Huck feels a deep sense of pity for the girls, knowing they are being deceived, but sees no way to intervene without endangering himself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.

events.text_segment:
They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy. But nothing come of it; the faces didn’t tell me nothing.
The king he visited around in the evening, and sweetened everybody up, and made himself ever so friendly; and he give out the idea that his congregation over in England would be in a sweat about him, so he must hurry and settle up the estate right away and leave for home. He was very sorry he was so pushed, and so was everybody; they wished he could stay longer, but they said they could see it couldn’t be done. And he said of course him and William would take the girls home with them; and that pleased everybody too, because then the girls would be well fixed and amongst their own relations; and it pleased the girls, too—tickled them so they clean forgot they ever had a trouble in the world; and told him to sell out as quick as he wanted to, they would be ready. Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didn’t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.

events.title: The Heartbreaking Sale and Separation of the Enslaved Family
characters: enslaved people (two sons and their mother)
detailed_summary: The King promptly arranges for the auction of the Wilks estate, including the house and the enslaved people, just two days after the funeral.
The day after the funeral, slave traders arrive, and the King sells the enslaved family—two sons are sent upriver to Memphis, and their mother downriver to New Orleans.
The separation causes immense grief for both the Wilks girls and the enslaved family, who cry and lament their parting.
The girls express their shock, never having imagined the enslaved family would be sold or separated.
Huck is profoundly moved by the scene, stating he could hardly bear it if he didn't know the sale was fraudulent and the enslaved individuals would likely be back in a short time.
The townspeople are also stirred by this event, with many openly condemning the separation of the mother and her children as scandalous.
This public outcry damages the reputation of the King and Duke, making the Duke particularly anxious, though the King stubbornly proceeds with his plans.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.

events.text_segment:
Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
So the next day after the funeral, along about noon-time, the girls’ joy got the first jolt. A couple of nigger traders come along, and the king sold them the niggers reasonable, for three-day drafts as they called it, and away they went, the two sons up the river to Memphis, and their mother down the river to Orleans. I thought them poor girls and them niggers would break their hearts for grief; they cried around each other, and took on so it most made me down sick to see it. The girls said they hadn’t ever dreamed of seeing the family separated or sold away from the town. I can’t ever get it out of my memory, the sight of them poor miserable girls and niggers hanging around each other’s necks and crying; and I reckon I couldn’t a stood it all, but would a had to bust out and tell on our gang if I hadn’t knowed the sale warn’t no account and the niggers would be back home in a week or two.
The thing made a big stir in the town, too, and a good many come out flatfooted and said it was scandalous to separate the mother and the children that way. It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.

events.title: The King and Duke Confront Huck About the Missing Money
detailed_summary: On the morning of the auction, the King and Duke awaken Huck, their expressions indicating trouble.
They interrogate Huck about whether he was in their room or saw anyone else enter it, suspecting the money is missing.
Huck denies being near their room since Mary Jane first showed it to them.
When pressed, Huck cleverly suggests he saw the enslaved individuals (referred to as 'niggers' by the characters) coming out of their room on the morning of the funeral, acting secretively.
The King and Duke are initially surprised, then seemingly convinced by Huck's implication that the enslaved people stole the money before being sold.
The Duke laments selling them so cheaply, believing they possessed significant 'histrionic talent' for feigning sorrow at their departure.
The King dismisses Huck sharply when he asks if something is wrong, telling him to mind his own business.
As they leave, the Duke makes a sarcastic comment about 'quick sales and small profits,' leading to an argument with the King about whose fault the supposed loss is.
The King then berates Huck for not informing him sooner about seeing the enslaved people in his room.
Huck feels relieved that he successfully diverted suspicion onto the enslaved people, especially since he believes they are safe and will not be harmed by his accusation, given their fraudulent sale.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Next day was auction day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.

events.text_segment:
Next day was auction day. About broad day in the morning the king and the duke come up in the garret and woke me up, and I see by their look that there was trouble. The king says:
“Was you in my room night before last?”
“No, your majesty”—which was the way I always called him when nobody but our gang warn’t around.
“Was you in there yisterday er last night?”
“No, your majesty.”
“Honor bright, now—no lies.”
“Honor bright, your majesty, I’m telling you the truth. I hain’t been a-near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke and showed it to you.”
The duke says:
“Have you seen anybody else go in there?”
“No, your grace, not as I remember, I believe.”
“Stop and think.”
I studied awhile and see my chance; then I says:
“Well, I see the niggers go in there several times.”
Both of them gave a little jump, and looked like they hadn’t ever expected it, and then like they had. Then the duke says:
“What, all of them?”
“No—leastways, not all at once—that is, I don’t think I ever see them all come out at once but just one time.”
“Hello! When was that?”
“It was the day we had the funeral. In the morning. It warn’t early, because I overslept. I was just starting down the ladder, and I see them.”
“Well, go on, go on! What did they do? How’d they act?”
“They didn’t do nothing. And they didn’t act anyway much, as fur as I see. They tiptoed away; so I seen, easy enough, that they’d shoved in there to do up your majesty’s room, or something, s’posing you was up; and found you warn’t up, and so they was hoping to slide out of the way of trouble without waking you up, if they hadn’t already waked you up.”
“Great guns, this is a go!” says the king; and both of them looked pretty sick and tolerable silly. They stood there a-thinking and scratching their heads a minute, and the duke he bust into a kind of a little raspy chuckle, and says:
“It does beat all how neat the niggers played their hand. They let on to be sorry they was going out of this region! And I believed they was sorry, and so did you, and so did everybody. Don’t ever tell me any more that a nigger ain’t got any histrionic talent. Why, the way they played that thing it would fool anybody. In my opinion, there’s a fortune in ’em. If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn’t want a better lay-out than that—and here we’ve gone and sold ’em for a song. Yes, and ain’t privileged to sing the song yet. Say, where is that song—that draft?”
“In the bank for to be collected. Where would it be?”
“Well, that’s all right then, thank goodness.”
Says I, kind of timid-like:
“Is something gone wrong?”
The king whirls on me and rips out:
“None o’ your business! You keep your head shet, and mind y’r own affairs—if you got any. Long as you’re in this town don’t you forgit that—you hear?” Then he says to the duke, “We got to jest swaller it and say noth’n’: mum’s the word for us.”
As they was starting down the ladder the duke he chuckles again, and says:
“Quick sales and small profits! It’s a good business—yes.”
The king snarls around on him and says:
“I was trying to do for the best in sellin’ ’em out so quick. If the profits has turned out to be none, lackin’ considable, and none to carry, is it my fault any more’n it’s yourn?”
“Well, they’d be in this house yet and we wouldn’t if I could a got my advice listened to.”
The king sassed back as much as was safe for him, and then swapped around and lit into me again. He give me down the banks for not coming and telling him I see the niggers come out of his room acting that way—said any fool would a knowed something was up. And then waltzed in and cussed himself awhile, and said it all come of him not laying late and taking his natural rest that morning, and he’d be blamed if he’d ever do it again. So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.

If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn't want a better lay-out than that—and here we've gone and sold 'em for a song. Yes, and ain't privileged to sing the song yet. Say, where IS that song—that draft?"

"In the bank for to be collected. Where WOULD it be?"

"Well, THAT'S all right then, thank goodness."

Says I, kind of timid-like:

"Is something gone wrong?"

The king whirls on me and rips out:

"None o' your business! You keep your head shet, and mind y'r own affairs—if you got any. Long as you're in this town don't you forgit THAT—you hear?" Then he says to the duke, "We got to jest swaller it and say noth'n': mum's the word for US."

As they was starting down the ladder the duke he chuckles again, and says:

"Quick sales AND small profits! It's a good business—yes."

The king snarls around on him and says:

"I was trying to do for the best in sellin' 'em out so quick. If the profits has turned out to be none, lackin' considable, and none to carry, is it my fault any more'n it's yourn?"

"Well, THEY'D be in this house yet and we WOULDN'T if I could 'a' got my advice listened to."

The king sassed back as much as was safe for him, and then swapped around and lit into ME again. He give me down the banks for not coming and TELLING him I see the niggers come out of his room acting that way—said any fool would 'a' KNOWED something was up. And then waltzed in and cussed HIMSELF awhile, and said it all come of him not laying late and taking his natural rest that morning, and he'd be blamed if he'd ever do it again. So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I'd worked it all off onto the niggers, and yet hadn't done the niggers no harm by it.
```

events.title: Huck Comforts Mary Jane and Reveals a Shocking Truth
detailed_summary: Huck, upon waking, finds Mary Jane crying in her room while packing for England, distressed about the separation of the enslaved family sold by the con men.
Feeling sympathy, Huck enters her room and tries to comfort her.
Mary Jane expresses her deep sorrow that the enslaved mother and children will never see each other again.
Impulsively, Huck blurts out that they will indeed be reunited within two weeks, a statement he knows to be true.

Taken aback by his own sudden revelation, Huck pauses to consider whether telling the full truth is wiser than concocting a lie in this difficult situation, ultimately deciding that the truth, though risky, seems safer.
He asks Mary Jane if she can go to a place out of town, Mr. Lothrop's, and stay for three or four days.
Huck strikes a deal with Mary Jane: if he proves how he knows the enslaved family will be reunited, she must go to Mr. Lothrop's and stay for the agreed time, to which she readily consents.
After securing her promise and bolting the door for privacy, Huck gravely informs Mary Jane that her supposed uncles are, in fact, frauds and 'dead-beats.'
Mary Jane is, of course, deeply shaken but then quickly consumed by rage, exclaiming that the impostors should be immediately tarred, feathered, and thrown into the river.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By-and-by it was getting-up time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”

events.text_segment:
By-and-by it was getting-up time. So I come down the ladder and started for down-stairs; but as I come to the girls’ room the door was open, and I see Mary Jane setting by her old hair trunk, which was open and she’d been packing things in it—getting ready to go to England. But she had stopped now with a folded gown in her lap, and had her face in her hands, crying. I felt awful bad to see it; of course anybody would. I went in there and says:
“Miss Mary Jane, you can’t a-bear to see people in trouble, and I can’t—most always. Tell me about it.”
So she done it. And it was the niggers—I just expected it. She said the beautiful trip to England was most about spoiled for her; she didn’t know how she was ever going to be happy there, knowing the mother and the children warn’t ever going to see each other no more—and then busted out bitterer than ever, and flung up her hands, and says:
“Oh, dear, dear, to think they ain’t ever going to see each other any more!”
“But they will—and inside of two weeks—and I know it!” says I.
Laws, it was out before I could think! And before I could budge she throws her arms around my neck and told me to say it again, say it again, say it again!
I see I had spoke too sudden and said too much, and was in a close place. I asked her to let me think a minute; and she set there, very impatient and excited and handsome, but looking kind of happy and eased-up, like a person that’s had a tooth pulled out. So I went to studying it out. I says to myself, I reckon a body that ups and tells the truth when he is in a tight place is taking considerable many resks, though I ain’t had no experience, and can’t say for certain; but it looks so to me, anyway; and yet here’s a case where I’m blest if it don’t look to me like the truth is better and actuly safer than a lie. I must lay it by in my mind, and think it over some time or other, it’s so kind of strange and unregular. I never see nothing like it. Well, I says to myself at last, I’m a-going to chance it; I’ll up and tell the truth this time, though it does seem most like setting down on a kag of powder and touching it off just to see where you’ll go to. Then I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, is there any place out of town a little ways where you could go and stay three or four days?”
“Yes; Mr. Lothrop’s. Why?”
“Never mind why yet. If I’ll tell you how I know the niggers will see each other again inside of two weeks—here in this house—and prove how I know it—will you go to Mr. Lothrop’s and stay four days?”
“Four days!” she says; “I’ll stay a year!”
“All right,” I says, “I don’t want nothing more out of you than just your word—I druther have it than another man’s kiss-the-Bible.” She smiled and reddened up very sweet, and I says, “If you don’t mind it, I’ll shut the door—and bolt it.”
Then I come back and set down again, and says:
“Don’t you holler. Just set still and take it like a man. I got to tell the truth, and you want to brace up, Miss Mary, because it’s a bad kind, and going to be hard to take, but there ain’t no help for it. These uncles of yourn ain’t no uncles at all; they’re a couple of frauds—regular dead-beats. There, now we’re over the worst of it, you can stand the rest middling easy.”
It jolted her up like everything, of course; but I was over the shoal water now, so I went right along, her eyes a-blazing higher and higher all the time, and told her every blame thing, from where we first struck that young fool going up to the steamboat, clear through to where she flung herself on to the king’s breast at the front door and he kissed her sixteen or seventeen times—and then up she jumps, with her face afire like sunset, and says:
“The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”

events.title: Huck Outlines a Plan for Justice and Mary Jane's Role
detailed_summary: Huck tempers Mary Jane's immediate desire for vengeance, reminding her to consider her actions carefully.
He explains that a premature exposure of the frauds would endanger another innocent person (Jim), whom they have a responsibility to protect.
Huck then lays out his plan: Mary Jane is to depart for Mr. Lothrop's place and remain there until nine or half-past nine that night.

If Huck hasn't returned by eleven o'clock, she should place a candle in her window as a signal; if he still hasn't appeared by eleven, it means he has escaped and is safe, at which point she can expose the con men and have them jailed.
He instructs Mary Jane that if he happens to be captured alongside the frauds, she must publicly declare that he had confided everything to her beforehand and offer him her full support.

To provide evidence against the con men, Huck writes 'Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville' on a piece of paper for Mary Jane, telling her to give it to the court so they can summon witnesses from that town who can identify the frauds.

Huck reassures her that the ongoing auction and the sale of the enslaved individuals are invalid and that the enslaved people will be returned, emphasizing that the con men are in a difficult position and won't be able to collect any money.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:
Says I:
“Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for Mr. Lothrop’s.”

events.text_segment:
Says I:
“Cert’nly. But do you mean before you go to Mr. Lothrop’s, or—”
“Oh,” she says, “what am I thinking about!” she says, and set right down again. “Don’t mind what I said—please don’t—you won’t, now, will you?” Laying her silky hand on mine in that kind of a way that I said I would die first. “I never thought, I was so stirred up,” she says; “now go on, and I won’t do so any more. You tell me what to do, and whatever you say I’ll do it.”
“Well,” I says, “it’s a rough gang, them two frauds, and I’m fixed so I got to travel with them a while longer, whether I want to or not—I druther not tell you why; and if you was to blow on them this town would get me out of their claws, and I’d be all right; but there’d be another person that you don’t know about who’d be in big trouble. Well, we got to save him, hain’t we? Of course. Well, then, we won’t blow on them.”
Saying them words put a good idea in my head. I see how maybe I could get me and Jim rid of the frauds; get them jailed here, and then leave. But I didn’t want to run the raft in the daytime without anybody aboard to answer questions but me; so I didn’t want the plan to begin working till pretty late to-night. I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, I’ll tell you what we’ll do, and you won’t have to stay at Mr. Lothrop’s so long, nuther. How fur is it?”
“A little short of four miles—right out in the country, back here.”
“Well, that’ll answer. Now you go along out there, and lay low till nine or half-past to-night, and then get them to fetch you home again—tell them you’ve thought of something. If you get here before eleven put a candle in this window, and if I don’t turn up wait till eleven, and then if I don’t turn up it means I’m gone, and out of the way, and safe. Then you come out and spread the news around, and get these beats jailed.”
“Good,” she says, “I’ll do it.”
“And if it just happens so that I don’t get away, but get took up along with them, you must up and say I told you the whole thing beforehand, and you must stand by me all you can.”
“Stand by you! indeed I will. They sha’n’t touch a hair of your head!” she says, and I see her nostrils spread and her eyes snap when she said it, too.
“If I get away I sha’n’t be here,” I says, “to prove these rapscallions ain’t your uncles, and I couldn’t do it if I was here. I could swear they was beats and bummers, that’s all, though that’s worth something. Well, there’s others can do that better than what I can, and they’re people that ain’t going to be doubted as quick as I’d be. I’ll tell you how to find them. Gimme a pencil and a piece of paper. There—‘Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.’ Put it away, and don’t lose it. When the court wants to find out something about these two, let them send up to Bricksville and say they’ve got the men that played the Royal Nonesuch, and ask for some witnesses—why, you’ll have that entire town down here before you can hardly wink, Miss Mary. And they’ll come a-biling, too.”
I judged we had got everything fixed about right now. So I says:
“Just let the auction go right along, and don’t worry. Nobody don’t have to pay for the things they buy till a whole day after the auction on accounts of the short notice, and they ain’t going out of this till they get that money; and the way we’ve fixed it the sale ain’t going to count, and they ain’t going to get no money. It’s just like the way it was with the niggers—it warn’t no sale, and the niggers will be back before long. Why, they can’t collect the money for the niggers yet—they’re in the worst kind of a fix, Miss Mary.”
“Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for Mr. Lothrop’s.”

She looked troubled at that, and I could see she was thinking hard.

"I'll tell you what to do," says I. "You go to Mr. Lothrop's and stay there till nine or half-past tonight. If you don't hear from me by eleven, put a candle in your window. That'll mean I've got away safe. Then you can come out with the whole story and have them jailed."

"And if they catch you too?" she says, her eyes all worried.

"Then you must stand by me," says I. "You must say I told you the whole thing beforehand, and you'll back me up. Here—" I scribbled on a piece of paper—"take this and keep it safe: 'Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.' Give that to the court, and they can send there for witnesses that know these frauds."

"What about the poor slaves?" she asks, her voice trembling.

"Don't you fret about that," says I. "The sale ain't legal, and they can't collect the money neither. Them poor niggers will be back soon enough. Your uncles are in a tight place, Miss Mary Jane, and they know it."

events.title: Mary Jane's Departure and a Final Revelation About the Money
detailed_summary: Huck advises Mary Jane to leave for Mr. Lothrop's before breakfast, arguing that her expressive face would inadvertently reveal her knowledge of the deception to her 'uncles'.
Mary Jane understands and agrees to go, but firmly states she will not send her love to the frauds, a sentiment Huck respects.
Huck then confesses to Mary Jane that he had stolen the bag of gold from the con men, intending to return it to her.
He explains that he was nearly caught and had to hide the money in the first available spot, expressing his deep regret that it might no longer be there and that the hiding place was not ideal.
Mary Jane consoles Huck, insisting it wasn't his fault.

Unwilling to verbally describe the grim location of the hidden money (Peter Wilks's coffin), Huck writes it down on a piece of paper for her to read on her way to Mr. Lothrop's: 'I put it in the coffin.'
Recalling Mary Jane's sorrow at the coffin, Huck is moved, and as he gives her the note, he sees tears in her eyes as well.
Mary Jane shakes his hand firmly, promises to follow all his instructions, and assures him she will never forget him and will pray for him, then departs.

Huck reflects on Mary Jane's remarkable character, her grit, goodness, and beauty, admitting he has thought of her countless times since her departure and is deeply touched by her promise to pray for him.

events.text_segment:
“’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
“Why?”
“What did you reckon I wanted you to go at all for, Miss Mary?”
“Well, I never thought—and come to think, I don’t know. What was it?”
“Why, it’s because you ain’t one of these leather-face people. I don’t want no better book than what your face is. A body can set down and read it off like coarse print. Do you reckon you can go and face your uncles when they come to kiss you good-morning, and never—”
“There, there, don’t! Yes, I’ll go before breakfast—I’ll be glad to. And leave my sisters with them?”
“Yes; never mind about them. They’ve got to stand it yet a while. They might suspicion something if all of you was to go. I don’t want you to see them, nor your sisters, nor nobody in this town; if a neighbor was to ask how is your uncles this morning your face would tell something. No, you go right along, Miss Mary Jane, and I’ll fix it with all of them. I’ll tell Miss Susan to give your love to your uncles and say you’ve went away for a few hours for to get a little rest and change, or to see a friend, and you’ll be back to-night or early in the morning.”
“Gone to see a friend is all right, but I won’t have my love given to them.”
“Well, then, it sha’n’t be.” It was well enough to tell her so—no harm in it. It was only a little thing to do, and no trouble; and it’s the little things that smooths people’s roads the most, down here below; it would make Mary Jane comfortable, and it wouldn’t cost nothing. Then I says: “There’s one more thing—that bag of money.”
“Well, they’ve got that; and it makes me feel pretty silly to think how they got it.”
“No, you’re out, there. They hain’t got it.”
“Why, who’s got it?”
“I wish I knowed, but I don’t. I had it, because I stole it from them; and I stole it to give to you; and I know where I hid it, but I’m afraid it ain’t there no more. I’m awful sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I’m just as sorry as I can be; but I done the best I could; I did honest. I come nigh getting caught, and I had to shove it into the first place I come to, and run—and it warn’t a good place.”
“Oh, stop blaming yourself—it’s too bad to do it, and I won’t allow it—you couldn’t help it; it wasn’t your fault. Where did you hide it?”
I didn’t want to set her to thinking about her troubles again; and I couldn’t seem to get my mouth to tell her what would make her see that corpse laying in the coffin with that bag of money on his stomach. So for a minute I didn’t say nothing; then I says:
“I’d ruther not tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don’t mind letting me off; but I’ll write it for you on a piece of paper, and you can read it along the road to Mr. Lothrop’s, if you want to. Do you reckon that’ll do?”
“Oh, yes.”
So I wrote: “I put it in the coffin. It was in there when you was crying there, away in the night. I was behind the door, and I was mighty sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane.”
It made my eyes water a little to remember her crying there all by herself in the night, and them devils laying there right under her own roof, shaming her and robbing her; and when I folded it up and give it to her I see the water come into her eyes, too; and she shook me by the hand, hard, and says:
“Good-bye. I’m going to do everything just as you’ve told me; and if I don’t ever see you again, I sha’n’t ever forget you and I’ll think of you a many and a many a time, and I’ll pray for you, too!”—and she was gone.
Pray for me! I reckoned if she knowed me she’d take a job that was more nearer her size. But I bet she done it, just the same—she was just that kind. She had the grit to pray for Judus if she took the notion—there warn’t no back-down to her, I judge. You may say what you want to, but in my opinion she had more sand in her than any girl I ever see; in my opinion she was just full of sand. It sounds like flattery, but it ain’t no flattery. And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all. I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.

events.title: Huck Deceives Susan and Joanna to Cover Mary Jane's Absence
detailed_summary: After Mary Jane secretly leaves, Huck approaches her sisters, Susan and Joanna (the 'hare-lip'), to explain Mary Jane's absence.
He initially tells them Mary Jane rushed off to visit a sick friend from across the river, named Hanner Proctor.

When pressed for details about Hanner's illness, Huck invents a complex and severe disease, describing it as a new kind of mumps mixed with measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, consumption, yellow jaundice, and brain fever.

He convinces the sisters that this 'pluribus-unum mumps' is highly contagious and that they shouldn't tell their 'uncles' about Mary Jane's exposure, as it would delay their trip to England for at least three months.
The sisters, eager to go to England, agree not to tell anyone, especially their 'uncles'.

Huck then refines the cover story, instructing the sisters to tell their 'uncles' that Mary Jane went to ask the wealthy Apthorp family to attend the auction and buy the house, as Peter Wilks would have wished it.
The sisters accept this explanation and go to inform the King and Duke, giving them Mary Jane's supposed love and kisses.

Huck feels satisfied with his elaborate deception, confident that the girls will remain silent due to their desire to go to England, and that the King and Duke will be content with Mary Jane being away, thus keeping her from encountering Doctor Robinson. He prides himself on handling the situation skillfully.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Everything was all right now. The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

events.text_segment:
Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. When I struck Susan and the hare-lip, I says:
“What’s the name of them people over on t’other side of the river that you all goes to see sometimes?”
They says:
“There’s several; but it’s the Proctors, mainly.”
“That’s the name,” I says; “I most forgot it. Well, Miss Mary Jane she told me to tell you she’s gone over there in a dreadful hurry—one of them’s sick.”
“Which one?”
“I don’t know; leastways, I kinder forget; but I thinks it’s—”
“Sakes alive, I hope it ain’t Hanner?”
“I’m sorry to say it,” I says, “but Hanner’s the very one.”
“My goodness, and she so well only last week! Is she took bad?”
“It ain’t no name for it. They set up with her all night, Miss Mary Jane said, and they don’t think she’ll last many hours.”
“Only think of that, now! What’s the matter with her?”
I couldn’t think of anything reasonable, right off that way, so I says:
“Mumps.”
“Mumps your granny! They don’t set up with people that’s got the mumps.”
“They don’t, don’t they? You better bet they do with these mumps. These mumps is different. It’s a new kind, Miss Mary Jane said.”
“How’s it a new kind?”
“Because it’s mixed up with other things.”
“What other things?”
“Well, measles, and whooping-cough, and erysiplas, and consumption, and yaller janders, and brain-fever, and I don’t know what all.”
“My land! And they call it the mumps?”
“That’s what Miss Mary Jane said.”
“Well, what in the nation do they call it the mumps for?”
“Why, because it is the mumps. That’s what it starts with.”
“Well, ther’ ain’t no sense in it. A body might stump his toe, and take pison, and fall down the well, and break his neck, and bust his brains out, and somebody come along and ask what killed him, and some numskull up and say, ‘Why, he stumped his toe.’ Would ther’ be any sense in that? No. And ther’ ain’t no sense in this, nuther. Is it ketching?”
“Is it ketching? Why, how you talk. Is a harrow catching—in the dark? If you don’t hitch on to one tooth, you’re bound to on another, ain’t you? And you can’t get away with that tooth without fetching the whole harrow along, can you? Well, these kind of mumps is a kind of a harrow, as you may say—and it ain’t no slouch of a harrow, nuther, you come to get it hitched on good.”
“Well, it’s awful, I think,” says the hare-lip. “I’ll go to Uncle Harvey and—”
“Oh, yes,” I says, “I would. Of course I would. I wouldn’t lose no time.”
“Well, why wouldn’t you?”
“Just look at it a minute, and maybe you can see. Hain’t your uncles obleegd to get along home to England as fast as they can? And do you reckon they’d be mean enough to go off and leave you to go all that journey by yourselves? You know they’ll wait for you. So fur, so good. Your uncle Harvey’s a preacher, ain’t he? Very well, then; is a preacher going to deceive a steamboat clerk? is he going to deceive a ship clerk?—so as to get them to let Miss Mary Jane go aboard? Now you know he ain’t. What will he do, then? Why, he’ll say, ‘It’s a great pity, but my church matters has got to get along the best way they can; for my niece has been exposed to the dreadful pluribus-unum mumps, and so it’s my bounden duty to set down here and wait the three months it takes to show on her if she’s got it.’ But never mind, if you think it’s best to tell your uncle Harvey—”
“Shucks, and stay fooling around here when we could all be having good times in England whilst we was waiting to find out whether Mary Jane’s got it or not? Why, you talk like a muggins.”
“Well, anyway, maybe you’d better tell some of the neighbors.”
“Listen at that, now. You do beat all for natural stupidness. Can’t you see that they’d go and tell? Ther’ ain’t no way but just to not tell anybody at all.”
“Well, maybe you’re right—yes, I judge you are right.”
“But I reckon we ought to tell Uncle Harvey she’s gone out a while, anyway, so he won’t be uneasy about her?”
“Yes, Miss Mary Jane she wanted you to do that. She says, ‘Tell them to give Uncle Harvey and William my love and a kiss, and say I’ve run over the river to see Mr.’—Mr.—what is the name of that rich family your uncle Peter used to think so much of?—I mean the one that—”
“Why, you must mean the Apthorps, ain’t it?”
“Of course; bother them kind of names, a body can’t ever seem to remember them, half the time, somehow. Yes, she said, say she has run over for to ask the Apthorps to be sure and come to the auction and buy this house, because she allowed her uncle Peter would ruther they had it than anybody else; and she’s going to stick to them till they say they’ll come, and then, if she ain’t too tired, she’s coming home; and if she is, she’ll be home in the morning anyway. She said, don’t say nothing about the Proctors, but only about the Apthorps—which’ll be perfectly true, because she is going there to speak about their buying the house; I know it, because she told me so herself.”
“All right,” they said, and cleared out to lay for their uncles, and give them the love and the kisses, and tell them the message.
Everything was all right now. The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
# text_segment

Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. When I got by myself I went to thinking the thing over. I says to myself, shall I go down and tell them what that paper has got in it? No—that won't do. The thing might get out then and maybe ruin everything. They've got that money, and they'd slide right out and get away with it. If I was to put the girls wise, they might round them up before they could get very far. No, there ain't nothing to do but just hold still, and now let them take the money and get away with it. But I knowed I had got to speak up about the girls going to England and fix it up with the girls so they wouldn't worry about it.

So I went up stairs. When I got there they was in their room, and both of them had been crying. This made me feel pretty sorry for them. I knocked, and they told me to come in. I come in, and shut the door easy behind me, and says:

"Miss Susan, Miss Joanna, I can't ever tell you how sorry I am for what I done, but I ain't going to try; and I ain't going to make no excuses, but just ask you to forgive me, that's all."

Well, they was the best kind of girls. They didn't say a word, but just grabbed me and hung onto me and cried and cried; and I drawed back and says:

"Please don't—please don't. I can't bear it. I come to tell you something, and I thought maybe you'd be a little spiteful to me for helping the others to fool you and your sisters, and so I couldn't look you in the face if I had to tell you the news by myself; but Mary Jane she told me to tell you, and so I come."

"Mary Jane? Is she gone?"

"Yes'm."

"For good?"

"No'm. Not for good, but just for to-day; and not for to-day, nuther, but just for to-night—I mean, the doctor says, as fur as he can tell, she'll be all right by to-morrow."

"Where's she gone to, then?"

I couldn't think up any way to get around it right off, so I says:

"She's gone over to see that—that sick friend of hers, Hanner Proctor."

"What sick friend?"

"I don't know; leastways, I kinder forget; but I thinks it's—"

"Sakes alive, I hope it ain't Hanner Proctor. Why, she's been dead ever so long!"

I see I had slipped up, and I felt pretty cheap. I says:

"She—the—well, I must a been thinking about somebody else. Oh, I know—it's Hannah Bell."

"My goodness—Hannah Bell! What's the matter with her?"

"Oh, she's sick, and so's the whole family. Her uncle's broke his arm, and her two children is mighty bad off with the—the—well, they ain't expected to live till morning, and her sister Jane's got the mumps, and the mumps is spreading around, and I think they say her husband's took it too, and they're down with the pluribus-unum mumps, and they're having an awful time."

"My land! And they call it the mumps?"

"That's what Miss Mary Jane said."

"Well, for the land's sake! What's it like?"

"It's kind of a harrow-tooth arrangement, and it ain't the same kind that we got here. It's a new kind. Miss Mary Jane said."

"How's it spread?"

"Spread? Why, it spreads all around—just goes a-raging."

"Why, Joanna, you question the boy every which way, and you see he's stuck. Can't you see that? What do you want to bother him for?"

"Well, Mary Jane told me to tell you she's gone over there to see—"

"Oh, your granny!" says the hare-lip, "do you reckon anybody's going to believe all that rubbage about all them people being sick, and all that? Shucks!"

I see it warn't no use trying to put it over, so I just says:

"Please to don't poke fun at me, Miss Joanna. I can't bear it. I'm telling you just as Mary Jane told me, and she said tell you to remember the things you promised about England."

That settled it. When I mentioned England, both of them looked like they'd been struck by lightning, and Susan, she says:

"I'll go to Uncle Harvey and—"

"Oh, yes," I says, "I'd do it. I'd do it if I was you. But the thing about it is, Mary Jane she wanted you to do something for her that you wouldn't tell nobody about, not even the uncles, for anything in the world. She said she'd tell you all about it day after to-morrow, when she got home from seeing Hannah Proctor."

"All right," they said, "we'll do it, whatever it is." Then I says:

"Well, she says, don't you tell Uncle Harvey and Uncle William about her being gone away to see Hannah Proctor to-day. She says, tell them she's gone over to town to see the Apthorps. You know, the rich family your uncle Peter used to think so much of? They're the ones that'll buy the house when it's sold, Mary Jane thinks."

"But what in the nation does she mean by that?" says the hare-lip.

"Well," I says, "it's my opinion she done it to get to England as quick as she could. She told me all about it yesterday, she says, 'they'll sell the house, and maybe they'll be gone before I get back,' she says. 'Now you tell them I've gone over to see the Apthorps, and I'll be back to-morrow,' she says; 'and tell them to be sure and not miss the auction.'"

"Just as true as I'm a-sitting here," I says, "I ain't told you no lie about it, Miss Mary Jane she told me to tell you, and I've done the best I could; I ain't had no time to practice, and I couldn't a done it all so sudden if I had."

"All right," they said, "we'll go and tell Uncle Harvey and Uncle William. But we won't say nothing about England, you know."

"No, you're to keep mum."

"All right," they said, and cleared out to lay for their uncles. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn't a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can't do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

Well, then I happened to think how they was going to get the word to Mary Jane. The girls would be back before she was, and they'd tell her the message, and she'd worry, not knowing what had become of me. So I says to myself, I must put in the day at the Apthorps' somehow, and if Mary Jane's there, all right, I'll tell her what the game is; and if she ain't, I'll leave her a note.

events.title: The Auction's Climax and the Arrival of True Claimants
detailed_summary: The auction of Peter Wilks's property takes place in the public square towards the end of the afternoon, proceeding slowly.
The King (the 'old man') is present next to the auctioneer, maintaining his fraudulent persona by interjecting with pious remarks and bits of Scripture.
The Duke is also active, mingling with the crowd and attempting to evoke sympathy with feigned sorrow.
After a lengthy process, nearly everything is sold, except for a small, insignificant lot in the graveyard which the King is eager to offload.
While they are still trying to sell this last piece of property, a steamboat arrives at the landing.
Within minutes, a noisy crowd disembarks from the steamboat, shouting, laughing, and creating a commotion as they make their way up from the river.
The newcomers dramatically announce their arrival, proclaiming themselves as the 'opposition line' and presenting 'two sets of heirs to old Peter Wilks,' offering the townspeople a choice.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Here’s your opposition line! here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”

events.text_segment:
Well, they held the auction in the public square, along towards the end of the afternoon, and it strung along, and strung along, and the old man he was on hand and looking his level pisonest, up there longside of the auctioneer, and chipping in a little Scripture now and then, or a little goody-goody saying of some kind, and the duke he was around goo-gooing for sympathy all he knowed how, and just spreading himself generly.
But by-and-by the thing dragged through, and everything was sold—everything but a little old trifling lot in the graveyard. So they’d got to work that off—I never see such a girafft as the king was for wanting to swallow everything. Well, whilst they was at it a steamboat landed, and in about two minutes up comes a crowd a-whooping and yelling and laughing and carrying on, and singing out:
“Here’s your opposition line! here’s your two sets o’ heirs to old Peter Wilks—and you pays your money and you takes your choice!”

events.title: Arrival of the True Heirs
detailed_summary: Two new individuals, an older gentleman and a younger man with his arm in a sling, are brought into town, causing amusement among the crowd.
Huck, the narrator, does not find the situation humorous and anticipates that the duke and king will be disconcerted.
Contrary to Huck's expectation, the duke acts innocently pleased, while the king feigns sorrow over the appearance of what he implies are more impostors.
Several prominent townspeople show their allegiance by gathering around the king.
The newly arrived older gentleman appears utterly perplexed by the situation.
He addresses the crowd, revealing an authentic English accent, different from the king's imitation.
He introduces himself as Harvey Wilks and his companion as his brother William, who is deaf, mute, and further hampered by a broken arm.
Harvey explains their recent misfortunes: William's injury and their baggage being mistakenly left at a different town upriver.
He asserts their true identities and declares their intention to prove them upon the arrival of their baggage in a day or two, stating they will wait at the local hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”

events.text_segment:
They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. And, my souls, how the people yelled and laughed, and kept it up. But I didn’t see no joke about it, and I judged it would strain the duke and the king some to see any. I reckoned they’d turn pale. But no, nary a pale did they turn. The duke he never let on he suspicioned what was up, but just went a goo-gooing around, happy and satisfied, like a jug that’s googling out buttermilk; and as for the king, he just gazed and gazed down sorrowful on them new-comers like it give him the stomach-ache in his very heart to think there could be such frauds and rascals in the world. Oh, he done it admirable. Lots of the principal people gethered around the king, to let him see they was on his side. That old gentleman that had just come looked all puzzled to death. Pretty soon he begun to speak, and I see straight off he pronounced like an Englishman—not the king’s way, though the king’s was pretty good for an imitation. I can’t give the old gent’s words, nor I can’t imitate him; but he turned around to the crowd, and says, about like this:
“This is a surprise to me which I wasn’t looking for; and I’ll acknowledge, candid and frank, I ain’t very well fixed to meet it and answer it; for my brother and me has had misfortunes; he’s broke his arm, and our baggage got put off at a town above here last night in the night by a mistake. I am Peter Wilks’ brother Harvey, and this is his brother William, which can’t hear nor speak—and can’t even make signs to amount to much, now’t he’s only got one hand to work them with. We are who we say we are; and in a day or two, when I get the baggage, I can prove it. But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”

events.title: The King's Deflection and Hines's Accusation
detailed_summary: As the genuine Wilks brothers depart for the hotel, the king vociferously derides their explanation, suggesting their misfortunes are fabrications typical of frauds.
The majority of the onlookers laugh in agreement with the king.
However, a small group, including Doctor Robinson and a lawyer named Levi Bell, who has just arrived by steamboat, remain unconvinced and are seen conferring quietly.
A local man, identified later as Hines, steps forward and directly confronts the king about his account of arriving in town.
The king reiterates his claim of arriving by steamboat from Cincinnati the evening before the funeral.
Hines sharply contradicts the king, stating he personally saw the king, along with Tim Collins and a boy, at 'the Pint' that very morning, having arrived in a canoe.
Doctor Robinson inquires if Hines would recognize the boy again.
Hines immediately points to Huck, confirming him as the boy he saw with the king.

Doctor Robinson then addresses the crowd, expressing his conviction that the king and duke are impostors and proposing they all go to the tavern to confront the two pairs of claimants to ascertain the truth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I reckon we’ll find out		something		before we get through.”

events.text_segment:
So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out:
“Broke his arm—very likely, ain’t it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that’s got to make signs, and ain’t learnt how. Lost their baggage! That’s mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!”
So he laughed again; and so did everybody else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now. And when the king got done this husky up and says:
“Say, looky here; if you are Harvey Wilks, when’d you come to this town?”
“The day before the funeral, friend,” says the king.
“But what time o’ day?”
“In the evenin’—’bout an hour er two before sundown.”
“How’d you come?”
“I come down on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”
“Well, then, how’d you come to be up at the Pint in the mornin’—in a canoe?”
“I warn’t up at the Pint in the mornin’.”
“It’s a lie.”
Several of them jumped for him and begged him not to talk that way to an old man and a preacher.
“Preacher be hanged, he’s a fraud and a liar. He was up at the Pint that mornin’. I live up there, don’t I? Well, I was up there, and he was up there. I see him there. He come in a canoe, along with Tim Collins and a boy.”
The doctor he up and says:
“Would you know the boy again if you was to see him, Hines?”
“I reckon I would, but I don’t know. Why, yonder he is, now. I know him perfectly easy.”
It was me he pointed at. The doctor says:
“Neighbors, I don’t know whether the new couple is frauds or not; but if these two ain’t frauds, I am an idiot, that’s all. I think it’s our duty to see that they don’t get away from here till we’ve looked into this thing. Come along, Hines; come along, the rest of you. We’ll take these fellows to the tavern and affront them with t’other couple, and I reckon we’ll find out something before we get through.”

'Broke his arm—very likely, ain't it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that's got to make signs, and ain't learnt how. Lost their baggage! That's mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!'

So he laughed again; and so did everybody else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now. And when the king got done this husky up and says:

'Say, looky here; if you are Harvey Wilks, when'd you come to this town?'

'The day before the funeral, friend,' says the king.

'But what time o' day?'

'In the evenin'—'bout an hour er two before sundown.'

'How'd you come?'

'I come down on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.'

'Well, then, how'd you come to be up at the Pint in the mornin'—in a canoe?'

'I warn't up at the Pint in the mornin'.'

'It's a lie.'

Several people jumped for him and begged him not to talk that way to an old man and a preacher.

'Preacher be hanged, he's a fraud and a liar. He was up at the Pint that mornin'. I live up there, don't I? Well, I was up there, and he was up there. I see him there. He come in a canoe, along with Tim Collins and a boy.'

The doctor he up and says:

'Would you know the boy again if you was to see him, Hines?'

'I reckon I would, but I don't know. Why, yonder he is, now. I know him perfectly easy.'

It was me he pointed at. The doctor says:

'Neighbors, I don't know whether the new couple is frauds or not; but if these two ain't frauds, I am an idiot, that's all. I think it's our duty to see that they don't get away from here till we've looked into this thing. Come along, Hines; come along, the rest of you. We'll take these fellows to the tavern and confront them with the Englishmen, and I reckon we'll find out something before we get through.'"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
"Broke his arm—very likely ain't it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that's got to make signs, and ain't learnt how. Lost their baggage! That's mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!"

So he laughed again; and so did I, thinking about how clever it was to pretend to be a deaf-mute Englishman when you couldn't even do the accent right. The king went on practicing his broken English, getting worse at it every minute, and it was hard not to laugh watching him make such a fool of himself.

By-and-by we got to the village. It was a good-sized little town nestled in the bend of the river. We tied up about half a mile above it, in the mouth of a creek which was shut in like a tunnel by the cypress trees, and all of us but Jim took the canoe and went down there to see about it.

We struck an old man paddling around in a canoe, and asked him if he knew a fellow named Wilks.

"No," says he.

"Maybe he's gone up to the town," says the duke. "Do you know anybody around here named Wilks, or ever did?"

"Well, lemme think. I reckon not. There was a Richard Wilks had a brick store here about twenty year ago, but he's been dead more'n ten year. There ain't been no other Wilks around that I remember."

"What was his first name?" says the duke.

"Richard."

"Was he rich?"

"Yes, he was pretty well off. He had houses and land, and it's reckoned he left three or four thousand in cash hid up som'ers."

"Is there anybody else of that name living around here?"

"No, nobody. There was a Peter Wilks had a little one-horse harness shop, but he ain't lived here for ten year or more—he died, and never left no family that I know of."

The duke asked some more questions, and the old man went on telling us all about the Wilkses, and about the town and the people. He said Peter and George were the only Wilks brothers he knew about. George was the married one, and had three daughters. Peter had no children. The old man said the three girls would be left a good deal of property when their uncle Peter died, which he reckoned must be very soon now, as Peter was reported to be on his deathbed.

The king was taking all this in, and I could see him getting more excited by the minute. I knew he was cooking up some new scheme, and sure enough, as soon as we got back to the raft, he and the duke started whispering together.

events.title: The Investigation Begins: The Missing Gold
detailed_summary: The crowd, eager for the confrontation, proceeds with all parties to a spacious room in the hotel, where candles are lit.
Doctor Robinson voices his suspicion that the king and duke are frauds and expresses concern that any accomplices they might have could escape with Peter Wilks's gold.
He suggests that if the king and duke are genuine, they should not oppose sending for the money and allowing the townsfolk to keep it safe until their identities are proven.
The king, affecting a sorrowful demeanor, agrees with the sentiment but declares that the money is unfortunately no longer where it was.
He fabricates a story, claiming he hid the gold inside his straw mattress for safekeeping, as he was unaccustomed to 'niggers' and assumed their honesty like English servants.
He alleges that the slaves, whom he subsequently sold, stole the gold the very next morning after he had hidden it, and he hadn't missed it before their departure.
He further states that his 'servant,' Huck, can attest to these events.
The doctor and several others react with audible disbelief to the king's tale.

When questioned, Huck claims he did not witness the slaves stealing the money but did see them surreptitiously leaving the room and hurrying away, which he had assumed was due to fear of having awakened his master.

events.text_segment:
It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started. It was about sundown. The doctor he led me along by the hand, and was plenty kind enough, but he never let go my hand.
We all got in a big room in the hotel, and lit up some candles, and fetched in the new couple. First, the doctor says:
“I don’t wish to be too hard on these two men, but I think they’re frauds, and they may have complices that we don’t know nothing about. If they have, won’t the complices get away with that bag of gold Peter Wilks left? It ain’t unlikely. If these men ain’t frauds, they won’t object to sending for that money and letting us keep it till they prove they’re all right—ain’t that so?”
Everybody agreed to that. So I judged they had our gang in a pretty tight place right at the outstart. But the king he only looked sorrowful, and says:
“Gentlemen, I wish the money was there, for I ain’t got no disposition to throw anything in the way of a fair, open, out-and-out investigation o’ this misable business; but, alas, the money ain’t there; you k’n send and see, if you want to.”
“Where is it, then?”
“Well, when my niece give it to me to keep for her I took and hid it inside o’ the straw tick o’ my bed, not wishin’ to bank it for the few days we’d be here, and considerin’ the bed a safe place, we not bein’ used to niggers, and suppos’n’ ’em honest, like servants in England. The niggers stole it the very next mornin’ after I had went down stairs; and when I sold ’em I hadn’t missed the money yit, so they got clean away with it. My servant here k’n tell you ’bout it, gentlemen.”
The doctor and several said “Shucks!” and I see nobody didn’t altogether believe him. One man asked me if I see the niggers steal it. I said no, but I see them sneaking out of the room and hustling away, and I never thought nothing, only I reckoned they was afraid they had waked up my master and was trying to get away before he made trouble with them. That was all they asked me.

**Simulated Output of generate_literary_segment**:

It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king's friends; so we all started. The whole town was flocking to the hotel, and we had to elbow our way through. They got a big room ready with plenty of candles, and when everybody was gathered, the doctor he ups and says:

"Gentlemen, there's a plain case here, if I ever saw one. These two strangers claim to be the Wilks brothers from England, but I have strong reason to believe they're impostors. What troubles me most is that they might have confederates that we don't know about, who could make off with Peter Wilks's money while we're arguing here. Now, if these men are really Harvey and William Wilks, they shouldn't object to having that money fetched and kept safe by responsible citizens until this matter is settled."

Everybody agreed that was sensible. The king looked mighty sorrowful, and puts on a face like he was deeply pained by such suspicion. Then he sighs and says:

"Gentlemen, I wish to Heaven I could produce that money for you, but the sad truth is, it ain't there no more where I put it."

Several voices cried out, "Where is it then? What's become of it?"

"Well, gentlemen," says the king, all pitiful-like, "I ain't accustomed to the ways of this country. In England, our servants are honest folk who wouldn't dream of stealing. So when I got that money, I thought the safest place would be right under me while I slept. I hid it in my straw tick, not knowing that niggers in this country ain't like servants in England. And next morning, before I missed it, them niggers had sold themselves off and run away with every blessed cent!"

The doctor he just snorted. "Preposterous!" he says, and others muttered similar sentiments.

"Young man," says the doctor, turning to me, "did you see these slaves steal that money?"

"No, sir," I says, "I didn't see 'em steal it, but I did see 'em sneaking out of the room early that morning, and they lit out mighty quick. I thought they was afraid they'd waked up my master, but maybe there was another reason."

events.title: Huck's Interrogation and Awkward Testimony
detailed_summary: Doctor Robinson abruptly turns his attention to Huck and questions if he is also English.
Huck affirms that he is, which elicits laughter and expressions of disbelief, such as 'Stuff!', from the doctor and others.
A lengthy and disorganized general investigation commences, continuing for hours without any mention of supper.
Both the king and the newly arrived old gentleman (the real Harvey Wilks) are compelled to share their respective narratives.
Huck privately observes that any unbiased person would easily discern that the old gentleman was telling the truth while the king was lying.
Eventually, Huck is called upon to provide his account of events.
The king gives Huck a subtle, sidelong glance, which Huck understands as a cue to support the king's version of the story.
Huck begins to invent details about their supposed life in Sheffield and information about the English Wilks family.
He does not get very far into his fabricated tale before Doctor Robinson starts to laugh.
Levi Bell, the lawyer, interjects, advising Huck to stop, remarking on his apparent lack of experience and skill in lying, and suggesting he needs more practice.
Although Huck doesn't appreciate the nature of the 'compliment,' he is relieved to be excused from further testimony.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then the doctor whirls on me and says:

events.text_segment:
Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
“Are you English, too?”
I says yes; and him and some others laughed, and said, “Stuff!”
Well, then they sailed in on the general investigation, and there we had it, up and down, hour in, hour out, and nobody never said a word about supper, nor ever seemed to think about it—and so they kept it up, and kept it up; and it was the worst mixed-up thing you ever see. They made the king tell his yarn, and they made the old gentleman tell his’n; and anybody but a lot of prejudiced chuckleheads would a seen that the old gentleman was spinning truth and t’other one lies. And by-and-by they had me up to tell what I knowed. The king he give me a left-handed look out of the corner of his eye, and so I knowed enough to talk on the right side. I begun to tell about Sheffield, and how we lived there, and all about the English Wilkses, and so on; but I didn’t get pretty fur till the doctor begun to laugh; and Levi Bell, the lawyer, says:
“Set down, my boy; I wouldn’t strain myself if I was you. I reckon you ain’t used to lying, it don’t seem to come handy; what you want is practice. You do it pretty awkward.”
I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.

events.title: The Handwriting Test Exposes Frauds but Adds Complexity
detailed_summary: As Doctor Robinson begins to speak, the king interrupts him to warmly greet Levi Bell, claiming that his deceased brother Peter often wrote about Bell.
The lawyer and the king shake hands and converse for a while, eventually stepping aside for a private discussion.
Following their conversation, the lawyer announces a plan involving an order that he will send, which should resolve the matter.
The king then sits down and, with some effort, scrawls something on a piece of paper.
When the pen is handed to the duke, he appears visibly ill for the first time but proceeds to write.
The lawyer then requests the newly arrived old gentleman (Harvey Wilks) and his brother (William Wilks) to write a line or two and sign their names.
The old gentleman writes, but his script is illegible to everyone.
The lawyer, looking very surprised, retrieves old letters from his pocket, purportedly from Harvey Wilks, and compares the handwriting.
He declares that the handwriting in the old letters does not match that of the king, the duke, or the new old gentleman, pointing out the king and duke's dismay at being caught.
He further comments that the new old gentleman's marks are not proper writing at all.
The new old gentleman explains that his mute brother William is the one who copies his letters, so the handwriting on the old documents is William's.
The lawyer, noting he also has letters from William, asks William to write, but Harvey explains William cannot write with his injured right hand and uses his left.
Harvey asks the lawyer to compare both sets of old letters, stating they are by the same hand (William's).

After examining them, the lawyer concedes a strong resemblance, admitting his current line of proof is partly foiled, but firmly reiterates that the king and duke are definitely not the Wilks brothers.

events.text_segment:
The doctor he started to say something, and turns and says:
“If you’d been in town at first, Levi Bell—” The king broke in and reached out his hand, and says:
“Why, is this my poor dead brother’s old friend that he’s wrote so often about?”
The lawyer and him shook hands, and the lawyer smiled and looked pleased, and they talked right along awhile, and then got to one side and talked low; and at last the lawyer speaks up and says:
“That’ll fix it. I’ll take the order and send it, along with your brother’s, and then they’ll know it’s all right.”
So they got some paper and a pen, and the king he set down and twisted his head to one side, and chawed his tongue, and scrawled off something; and then they give the pen to the duke—and then for the first time the duke looked sick. But he took the pen and wrote. So then the lawyer turns to the new old gentleman and says:
“You and your brother please write a line or two and sign your names.”
The old gentleman wrote, but nobody couldn’t read it. The lawyer looked powerful astonished, and says:
“Well, it beats me”—and snaked a lot of old letters out of his pocket, and examined them, and then examined the old man’s writing, and then them again; and then says: “These old letters is from Harvey Wilks; and here’s these two handwritings, and anybody can see they didn’t write them” (the king and the duke looked sold and foolish, I tell you, to see how the lawyer had took them in), “and here’s this old gentleman’s hand writing, and anybody can tell, easy enough, he didn’t write them—fact is, the scratches he makes ain’t properly writing at all. Now, here’s some letters from—”
The new old gentleman says:
“If you please, let me explain. Nobody can read my hand but my brother there—so he copies for me. It’s his hand you’ve got there, not mine.”
“Well!” says the lawyer, “this is a state of things. I’ve got some of William’s letters, too; so if you’ll get him to write a line or so we can com—”
“He can’t write with his left hand,” says the old gentleman. “If he could use his right hand, you would see that he wrote his own letters and mine too. Look at both, please—they’re by the same hand.”
The lawyer done it, and says:
“I believe it’s so—and if it ain’t so, there’s a heap stronger resemblance than I’d noticed before, anyway. Well, well, well! I thought we was right on the track of a solution, but it’s gone to grass, partly. But anyway, one thing is proved—these two ain’t either of ’em Wilkses”—and he wagged his head towards the king and the duke.
